dataset_title: AFM image Power Spectrum Density analysis class
dataset_description: list("AFMImagePSDAnalysis") handles an list(list("AFMImage")) roughness against lenghscale analysis Constructor method of AFMImagePSDAnalysis Class. Wrapper function AFMImagePSDAnalysis Method list("psd1d_breaks") returns a number of breaks to calculate PSD1D from PSD2D list("psd2d_maxHighLengthScale") returns the maximum lengthscale to be managed by PSD2D list("psd2d_truncHighLengthScale") returns if the lengthscale of PSD2D should be truncated list("psd1d") returns a data.table of psd in 1D list("psd2d") list("roughnessAgainstLengthscale") returns a data.table of roughnesses versus lengthscale list("intersections") returns a intersection numeric value
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: list("AFMImageVariogramAnalysis") manages the variogram analysis of an list(list("AFMImage")) Constructor method of AFMImageVariogramAnalysis Class. dataset_description: DCLHb is a treatment solution contain oxygen carrying hemoglobin. dataset_description: The data correspond to an experiment with costanero sweetpotato made at the locality of the Tacna department, southern Peru. The effect of two viruses (Spfmv and Spcsv) was studied. The treatments were the following: CC (Spcsv) = Sweetpotato chlorotic dwarf, FF (Spfmv) = Feathery mottle, FC (Spfmv y Spcsv) = Viral complex and OO (witness) healthy plants. In each plot, 50 sweetpotato plants were sown and 12 plots were employed. Each treatment was made with 3 repetitions and at the end of the experiment the total weight in kilograms was evaluated. The virus transmission was made in the cuttings and these were sown in the field.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 12 observations on the following 2 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("virus")), list("a factor with levels ", list("cc"), " ", list("fc"), " ", list("ff"), " ", list("oo"))), "
", "    ", list(list(list("yield")), list("a numeric vector")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: International Potato Center. CIP - Lima Peru

dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Section 3.1

dataset_title: Data for red squirrels in Switzerland
dataset_description: A file with detection/nondetection data for the red squirrel in 265 1 km2 survey quadrats in Switzerland for 2007, together with covariates. See Examples for code to load the data.
dataset_format:
The file list("SwissSquirrels.txt") is a tab-delimited text file with 265 rows and the following columns: list("
", "      ", list(), " spec.name : the species name.
", "      ", list(), " coordx : the x coordinate of the centre of the quadrat; the coordinate reference system intentionally not specified.
", "      ", list(), " coordy : the y coordinate of the centre of the quadrat.
", "      ", list(), " ele : the mean elevation of the quadrat, m.
", "      ", list(), " route : the length of the route walked in the quadrat, km.
", "      ", list(), " forest : percentage forest cover.
", "      ", 
    list(), " det071,	det072,	det073 : 1/0 detection data for 3 survey occasions in 2007.
", "      ", list(), " date071, date072, date073 : Julian date for the 3 survey occasions (1 = 1st April).
", "      ", list(), " dur071, dur072, dur073 : duration of the 3 survey occasions (mins).
", "    ")
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Section 10.9

dataset_title: Time-to-detection data for peregrines from the French Jura mountains
dataset_description: Between 7 and 9 March 2015, 38 breeding cliffs were visited up to 3 times. Observation duration varied from 3 to 95 minutes. The time to detection was recorded for each bird seen. If no birds were seen, the time was entered as NA.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 70 rows and the following columns: list("
", "  ", list(list("Date "), list("a factor with 3 levels giving the date")), "
", "  ", list(list("DayNumber "), list("the number of the day: 1, 2, or 3")), "
", "  ", list(list("SiteNumber "), list("identification number of the site")), "
", "  ", list(list("Start.hour, Start.minute "), list("the time of starting the search")), "
", "  ", list(list("End.hour, End.minute "), list("the time of ending the search")), "
", "  ", list(list("MinOfDay "), list("the time of the start of the search, minutes after 06:00")), 
    "
", "  ", list(list("Tmax "), list("the duration of the search, minutes")), "
", "  ", list(list("ttd "), list("the time to detection, minutes; NA if no birds were seen during the search")), "
", "  ", list(list("sex "), list("the sex of the birds seen; NA if no birds were seen")), "
", "  
", "  ")
dataset_source: Data provided with the AHM book at list("https://www.mbr-pwrc.usgs.gov/pubanalysis/keryroylebook/")
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Section 10.12

dataset_description: The Dutch Centre for Field Ornithology Sovon monitored grassland birds in Flevoland between April and mid-July 2011. 235 points were surveyed on up to 4 occasions; observations were divided into distance classes 50m wide, and the number of observations in each class recorded. These data are for yellow wagtails.
dataset_format:
list("wagtail") is a list with 8 elements: list("
", "  ", list(list("potato "), list("for each point, the percentage of the area which are potato fields.")), "
", "  ", list(list("grass "), list("for each point, the percentage of the area under permanent grassland.")), "
", "  ", list(list("lscale "), list("for each point, an index of whether the landscape is open (0) or closed (100).")), "
", "  ", list(list("date "), list("a points x occasions matrix, the Julian date of the survey.")), "
", "  ", list(list("hour "), list("a points x occasions matrix, the hour of the survey.")), 
    "
", "  ", list(list("breaks "), list("the boundaries between the distance classes; birds more than 300m from the point were not included.")), "
", "  ", list(list("Y "), list("a matrix of counts, with a row for each site; columns 1 to 6 give the counts in the distance classes for the 1st survey occasion, columns 7 to 12 for the 2nd occasion, and so on (this is the format required for ", list("unmarkedFrameGDS"), ").")), "
", "  ", list(list("rep "), list("a points x occasions character matrix with the occasion number (this is used as a categorical variable in the analysis).")), 
    "
")
dataset_source: Data provided with the AHM book at list("https://www.mbr-pwrc.usgs.gov/pubanalysis/keryroylebook/")
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Section 9.5.3

dataset_title: Functions and data for the Book 'Applied Hierarchical Modeling in Ecology'
dataset_description: Provides functions and data sets needed to run the code given in the two-volume publication, list("Applied Hierarchical Modeling in Ecology: analysis of distribution, abundance and species richness in R and BUGS") by Marc Kéry and Andy Royle, Academic Press (Vol 1, 2016; Vol 2, in preparation).
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Data from surveys of birds in Finnmark in NE Norway
dataset_description: A total of 37 plots were placed spanning the existing variation in extent and fragmentation of willow thickets. Each plot was visited 3-5 times in early July each year from 2005 to 2008. Birds observed within 100m during a 15 min period were recorded.
dataset_format:
list("Finnmark") is a list with 4 elements: list("
", "  ", list(list(list("species ")), list("a data frame with a row for each species and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " species : the English name.
", "      ", list(), " latin : the Latin name.
", "      ", list(), " assemblage : the guild of the species.
", "    ")))) list("    
", "  ", list(list(list("sites ")), list("a data frame with a row for each plot and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " region : a factor, 3 levels, Ilford, Komag, and Vestre Jakobselv.
", "      ", list(), " catchment : a factor, 11 levels.
", "      ", list(), " plot : a factor, the alphanumeric ID of each plot.
", "      ", list(), " plotnr : the ID number of each plot.
", "      ", list(), " area : the percentage of a 400 x 400m quadrat centred on the sampling point covered by tall willow thickets.
", 
    "      ", list(), " edge : the length (m) of the edge of the willow thickets in the quadrat.
", "      ", list(), " height : the mean height of willows at 4 measuring points.
", "      ", list(), " density : a measure of thicket density at 4 measuring points.
", "    ")))) list("    
", "  ", list(list(list("counts ")), list("a sites x replicates x years x species array of counts")), "
", "
", "  ", list(list(list("timeOfDay ")), list("a sites x replicates x years array with the time of day that the survey was carried out.")), "
")
dataset_source: Data generously provided by Jon-Andren Henden.
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Chapter 17 Henden J-A, Yoccoz NG, Ims RA, Langeland K (2013) How Spatial Variation in Areal Extent and Configuration of Labile Vegetation States Affect the Riparian Bird Community in Arctic Tundra. PLoS ONE 8(5): e63312.

dataset_title: Data from the Swiss Breeding Bird Survey 2014
dataset_description: The Swiss breeding bird survey ("Monitoring Häufige Brutvögel" MHB) has monitored the populations of 150 common species since 1999. The MHB sample consists of 267 1-km squares that are laid out as a grid across Switzerland. Fieldwork is conducted by about 200 skilled birdwatchers, most of them volunteers. Avian populations are monitored using a simplified territory mapping protocol, where each square is surveyed up to three times during the breeding season (only twice above the tree line). Surveys are conducted along a transect that does not change over the years. The list list("MHB2014") has the data for 2014.
dataset_format:
list("MHB2014") is a list with 5 elements: list("
", "  ", list(list(list("species ")), list("a data frame with row for 158 species, including 13 species not recorded in 2014, and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " specid : a numeric species ID based on phylogeny.
", "      ", list(), " latabb : a 6-letter abbreviation of the Latin name.
", "      ", list(), " engname : the English name.
", "      ", list(), " latname : the Latin name.
", "      ", list(), " body.length : body length in cm.
", "      ", 
    list(), " body.mass : body mass in g.
", "      ", list(), " wing.span : wing span in cm.
", "    ")))) list("
", "  ", list(list(list("sites ")), list("a data frame with rows for 267 1x1 km quadrat, including 1 quadrat not surveyed in 2014, and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " siteID : an alphanumeric site identifier.
", "      ", list(), " coordx : the x coordinate of the centre of the quadrat; the coordinate reference system intentionally not specified.
", "      ", list(), " coordy : the y coordinate of the centre of the quadrat.
", "      ", list(), " elev : the mean elevation of the quadrat, m.
", 
    "      ", list(), " rlength : the length of the route walked in the quadrat, km.
", "      ", list(), " nsurvey : the number of replicate surveys ", list("planned"), " in the quadrat; above the tree-line 2, otherwise 3.
", "      ", list(), " forest : percentage forest cover.
", "      ", list(), " obs14 : identifying number of the observer.
", "    ")))) list("
", "  ", list(list(list("counts ")), list("a sites x replicates x species array of counts")), "
", "
", "  ", list(list(list("date ")), list("a sites x replicates matrix with Julian dates of the surveys, 1 April = 1")), "
", "
", "  ", list(list(list("dur ")), list("a sites x replicates matrix with the duration of each survey, mins")), "
")
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Section 11.3

dataset_title: Data from the Swiss Breeding Bird Survey for 6 species of tits
dataset_description: The Swiss breeding bird survey ("Monitoring Häufige Brutvögel" MHB) has monitored the populations of 150 common species since 1999. The MHB sample consists of 267 1-km squares that are laid out as a grid across Switzerland. Fieldwork is conducted by about 200 skilled birdwatchers, most of them volunteers. Avian populations are monitored using a simplified territory mapping protocol, where each square is surveyed up to three times during the breeding season (only twice above the tree line). Surveys are conducted along a transect that does not change over the years. The list list("SwissTits") has the data for six species of tits from 2004 to 2013. There are some missing values: see Details.
dataset_format:
list("SwissTits") is a list with 5 elements: list("
", "  ", list(list(list("species ")), list("a data frame with a row for each species and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " specid : a numeric species ID based on phylogeny.
", "      ", list(), " latname : a 6-letter abbreviation of the Latin name.
", "      ", list(), " name : the English name.
", "    ")))) list("
", "  ", list(list(list("sites ")), list("a data frame with a row for each 1x1 km quadrat and the following columns:
", "
", "    ", list("
", "      ", list(), " siteID : an alphanumeric site identifier.
", "      ", list(), " coordx : the x coordinate of the centre of the quadrat; the coordinate reference system intentionally not specified.
", "      ", list(), " coordy : the y coordinate of the centre of the quadrat.
", "      ", list(), " AQ : an identifier for the 10km x 10km "Atlas Quadrat" within which the site falls.
", 
    "      ", list(), " AQ.coordx : the x coordinate of the centre of the AQ.
", "      ", list(), " AQ.coordy : the y coordinate of the centre of the AQ.
", "      ", list(), " elev : the mean elevation of the quadrat, m.
", "      ", list(), " rlength : the length of the route walked in the quadrat, km.
", "      ", list(), " forest : percentage forest cover.
", "    ")))) list("
", "  ", list(list(list("counts ")), list("a sites x replicates x years x species array of counts")), "
", "
", "  ", list(list(list("date ")), list("a sites x replicates x years array with Julian dates of the surveys, 1 April = 1")), "
", "
", "  ", list(list(list("dur ")), list("a sites x replicates x years array with the duration of each survey, mins")), "
")
dataset_reference: Kéry & Royle (2016) list("Applied Hierarachical Modeling in Ecology") Sections 6.9.1 and 6.13.1.

dataset_description: This simulated data set by Mazerolle (2015) is based on the biological parameters for the Gopher Tortoise ( list("Gopherus polyphemus") ) reported by Smith et al. (2009).  A half-normal distribution with a scale of 10 and without an  adjustment factor was used to simulate the distance data for a study area of 120 list(list("km^2")) . An effort of 500 m in 300 line transects was deployed. A density of 72 individuals per was used in the simulation using the approach outlined in Buckland et al. (2001).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 410 observations on the following 5 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("Region.Label")), list("a numeric identifier for the study area.")), " 
", "    ", list(list(list("Area")), list("a numeric variable for the surface area of the
", "      study area in square meters.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Sample.Label")), list("a numeric identifier for each line
", "      transect relating each observation to its corresponding transect.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Effort")), list("Effort in meters expended in each line transect.")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("distance")), list("a numeric variable for the perpendicular
", "      distances in meters relative to the transect line for each of the
", "      individuals detected during the survey. Note that transects
", "      without detections have a value of NA for this variable.")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: Buckland, S. T., Anderson, D. R., Burnham, K. P., Laake, J. L., Borchers, D. L., Thomas, L. (2001) list("Introduction to distance\n", "    sampling: estimating abundance of biological populations.") Oxford University Press: Oxford. Mazerolle, M. J. (2015) Estimating detectability and biological parameters of interest with the use of the R environment. list("Journal of Herpetology") list("49") , 541--559. Smith, L. L., Linehan, J. M., Stober, J. M., Elliott, M. J., Jensen, J. B. (2009) An evaluation of distance sampling for large-scale gopher tortoise surveys in Georgia, USA. list("Applied Herpetology") list("6") , 355--368.

(1965) Survival and breeding structure in a population of list("Ambystoma maculatum") . list("Copeia") list("1965") , 352--362. Jolly, G. M. (1965) Explicit estimates from capture-recapture data with both death and immigration: stochastic model. list("52") , 225--247. Laake, J. L. (2013) list("RMark: an R interface for analysis of\n", "  capture-recapture data with MARK.") dataset_description: This is a capture-mark-recapture data set on adult male and female Red-spotted Newts ( list("Notophthalmus viridescens") ) recorded by Gill (1985).  A total of 1079 unique individuals were captured in pitfall traps at a breeding site (White Oak Flat pond, Virginia) between 1975 and 1983.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 78 observations on the following 11 variables. list("

dataset_title: Model Selection and Multimodel Inference Based on (Q)AIC(c)
dataset_description: Description:  This package includes functions to create model selection tables based on Akaike's information criterion (AIC) and the second-order AIC (AICc), as well as their quasi-likelihood counterparts (QAIC, QAICc).  The package also features functions to conduct classic model averaging (multimodel inference) for a given parameter of interest or predicted values, as well as a shrinkage version of model averaging parameter estimates.  Other handy functions enable the computation of relative variable importance, evidence ratios, and confidence sets for the best model.  The present version works with Cox proportional hazards models and conditional logistic regression ( list("coxph") and list("coxme") classes), linear models ( list("lm") class), generalized linear models ( list("glm") , list("vglm") list("hurdle") , and list("zeroinfl") classes), linear models fit by generalized least squares ( list("gls") class), linear mixed models ( list("lme") linear mixed models ( list("mer") list("merMod") classes), multinomial and ordinal logistic regressions ( list("multinom") list("polr") list("clm") list("clmm") classes), robust regression models list("rlm") class), beta regression models ( list("betareg") class), parametric survival models ( list("survreg") class), nonlinear models list("nls") list("gnls") classes), nonlinear mixed models list("nlme") list("nlmerMod") classes), univariate models list("fitdist") list("fitdistr") classes), and certain types of latent variable models ( list("lavaan") class).  The package also supports various models of list("unmarkedFit") list("maxLikeFit") classes estimating demographic parameters after accounting for imperfect detection probabilities.  Some functions also allow the creation of model selection tables for Bayesian models of the list("bugs") list("rjags") classes.  Objects following model selection and multimodel inference can be formatted to LaTeX using list("xtable") methods included in the package.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference:
Anderson, D. R. (2008) list("Model-based inference in the life sciences:
", "    a primer on evidence") . Springer: New York. Burnham, K. P., and Anderson, D. R. (2002) list("Model selection and
", "    multimodel inference: a practical information-theoretic approach") . Second edition. Springer: New York. Burnham, K. P., Anderson, D. R. (2004) Multimodel inference: understanding AIC and BIC in model selection. list("Sociological
", "    Methods and Research") list("33") , 261--304. Mazerolle, M. J. (2006) Improving data analysis in herpetology: using Akaike's Information Criterion (AIC) to assess the strength of biological hypotheses. list("Amphibia-Reptilia") list("27") , 169--180.

dataset_description: This dataset contains the Leptospira interrogans MS data from Ludwig C., et al. (2012).
dataset_format: The data structure for LUDWIG_SRM represents a data.frame containing the following column header: list("\"run_id\"") (freetext), list("\"protein_id\"") list("\"peptide_id\"") list("\"transition_id\"") list("\"peptide_sequence\"") (unmodified, natural amino acid sequence in 1-letter nomenclature), list("\"precursor_charge\"") (positive integer value), list("\"transition_intensity\"") (positive non-logarithm floating value) and list("\"concentration\"") (calibration: positive non-logarithm floating value, prediction: "?").
dataset_reference: Ludwig, C., Claassen, M., Schmidt, A. & Aebersold, R. list("Estimation of Absolute Protein Quantities of Unlabeled Samples by Selected Reaction Monitoring Mass Spectrometry.") Molecular & Cellular Proteomics 11, M111.013987-M111.013987 (2012).

dataset_title: Calculating absolute and relative protein abundance from mass spectrometry-based protein expression data.
dataset_description: We assessed the performance of aLFQ and the different quantification estimation methods it supports by investigating a commercially available synthetic sample. The Universal Proteomic Standard 2 (UPS2) consists of 48 proteins spanning a dynamic range of five orders of magnitude in bins of eight proteins. The sample was measured in a complex background consisting of Mycobacterium bovis BCG total cell lysate in shotgun and targeted MS modes. Three datasets are available: UPS2_SC (spectral counts), UPS2_LFQ (MS1 intensity), UPS2_SRM (MS2 intensity).
dataset_format: The data structure for UPS2_SRM represents a data.frame containing the following column header: list("\"run_id\"") (freetext), list("\"protein_id\"") list("\"peptide_id\"") list("\"transition_id\"") list("\"peptide_sequence\"") (unmodified, natural amino acid sequence in 1-letter nomenclature), list("\"precursor_charge\"") (positive integer value), list("\"transition_intensity\"") (positive non-logarithm floating value) and list("\"concentration\"") (calibration: positive non-logarithm floating value, prediction: "?"). The data structure for UPS2_LFQ (MS1-level intensity) / UPS2_SC (spectral counts) represents a data.frame containing the columns list("\"peptide_intensity\"") (calibration: positive non-logarithm floating value, prediction: "?"). It should be noted, that the spectral count value is also represented by .

dataset_title: AlignStat: A tool for the statistical comparison of alternative multiple sequence alignments
dataset_description: This package contains functions that compare two alternative multiple sequence alignments (MSAs) to determine whether they align homologous residues in the same columns as one another. It then classifies similarities and differences into conserved gaps, conserved sequence, merges, splits or shifts of one MSA relative to the other. Summarising these categories for each MSA column yields information on which sequence regions are agreed upon my both MSAs, and which differ. Several plotting functions enable easily visualisation of the comparison data for analysis.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: An IPA-ASCII character map used for transforming IPA sequence into ASCII characters used by the C++ program. ALINE.map() is used internally by various functions. The original mapping schema is defined in (Kondrak 1999). The values provided here were derived from an Indonesian database so additional user-mappings for use with other lanugauge families can be enabled. Unicode interger values are stored in the dataframe. To view IPA see show.map().
dataset_format:
A data frame with 102 observations on the following 4 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("Aline")), list("A column of ALINE symbols ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("U.Val")), list("Unicode encoding for the IPA character.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("A.Val")), list("Unicode value(s) for the ALINE character(s).")), "
")
dataset_reference: Kondrak, G. (1999). Alignment of Phonetic Sequences. Technical Report CSRG-402. Department of Computer Science, University of Toronto.

dataset_title: Data sets to support the tutorials in the supplementary documentation and examples in the manual.
dataset_description: list("amExample1") High quality data set list() list("amExample2") Good quality data set list("amExample3") Marginal quality data set list("amExample4") Low quality data set list("amExample5") Wildlife data set Data sets 1 to 4 are simulated.  Because the data are simulated, the individual from which the samples are derived is known.  This is given in the column knownIndividual, and permits an assessment of how effective the software has been. Data set 5 is a real dataset from a wildlife population that has been non-invasively sampled.  The meta-data has been fabricated.  It represents the output from allele calling software.
dataset_format: Data frames with differing numbers of samples in rows, and alleles in columns.  Missing data is represented as "-99".

dataset_description: This package provides tools for the identification of unique of multilocus genotypes when both genotyping error and missing data may be present. The package is targeted at those working with large datasets and databases containing multiple samples of each individual, a situation that is common in conservation genetics, and particularly in non-invasive wildlife sampling applications. Functions explicitly incorporate missing data, and can tolerate allele mismatches created by genotyping error.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Langfelder P, Zhang B, Horvath S. (2008) Defining clusters from a hierarchical cluster tree: the Dynamic Tree Cut package for R. list("Bioinformatics") , 24, 719

dataset_title: Data inspired by GC mass spectrometry experiments
dataset_description: Data inspired by GC mass spectrometry experiments.
dataset_format: list("d1") and list("d2") are matrices of dimension 80 by 400 representing time and m/z resolved data. list("x") list("x2") represent the 80 times and 400 m/z values represented by the data, respectively. list("Cstart1") list("Cstart2") 80 by 2, representing starting values for elution profiles. list("S") represents mass spectra known to be represented in the data, as a 400 by 2 matrix.

dataset_title: Data inspired by GC mass spectrometry experiments
dataset_description: Data inspired by GC mass spectrometry experiments.
dataset_format: list("PsiList") is a list of 15 matrices of dimension 81 by 165, each representing time and m/z resolved data. list("WList") is a list of 15 matrices of dimension 81 by 165, in which each point is a weight to be applied to a given data point. list("xm") and list("xm2") represent the 81 times and 165 m/z values represented by each dataset in , respectively. list("AList") is a list of length 15, the elements of which represent estimates for the amplitude of each component in each of the 15 datasets. list("C1") is a 81 by 2 matrix representing a starting value for the shape of the elution profiles. list("Sm") represents mass spectra known to be represented in the data, as a 165 by 2 matrix.

dataset_title: Economic and Political Indictors in 6 African States
dataset_description: Data on a few economic and political variables in six African States from 1972-1991. The variables are year, country name, Gross Domestic Product per capita, inflation, trade as a percentage of GDP, a measure of civil liberties and total population. The data is from the Africa Research Program. A few cells are missing.
dataset_format: A data frame with 7 variables and 120 observations.

dataset_title: Trade Policy and Democracy in 9 Asian States
dataset_description: Economic and political data on nine developing countries in Asia from 1980 to 1999. This dataset includes 9 variables including year, country, average tariff rates, Polity IV score, total population, gross domestic product per capita, gross international reserves, a dummy variable for if the country had signed an IMF agreement in that year, a measure of financial openness, and a measure of US hegemony. These data were used in Milner and Kubota (2005).
dataset_format: A data frame with 10 variables and 171 observations.
dataset_source: World Bank, World Trade Organization, Polity IV and others.
dataset_reference: Helen Milner and Keiko Kubota (2005), ``Why the move to free trade? Democracy and trade policy in the developing countries.'' list("International Organization") , Vol 59, Issue 1.

dataset_title: Amelia II: A Program for Missing Data
dataset_description: Uses a bootstrap+EM algorithm to impute missing values from a dataset and produces multiple output datasets for analysis.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: James Honaker, Gary King, Matthew Blackwell (2011). Amelia II: A Program for Missing Data. list("Journal of Statistical Software") , list("45(7)") , 1--47. URL http://www.jstatsoft.org/v45/i07/. King, Gary; James Honaker, Anne Joseph, and Kenneth Scheve. \"Analyzing Incomplete Political Science Data: An Alternative Algorithm for Multiple Imputation\", list("American Political Science Review") , Vol. 95, No. 1 (March, 2001): Pp. 49-69.

dataset_title: Genetic and Phenotype Data of a Wheat Breeding Population
dataset_description: This data set gives the genetic marker information (DArT markers), phenotype, and the kinship matrix of a wheat breeding population.  The list wheat contains three elelments, 'y', 'marker' and 'A'.  The vector 'y' contains the phenotypic values for 282 wheat accessions, 'A' is a relationship (kinship) matrix of all the wheat accessions, and 'marker' is a 282 by 300 data frame for the genotype on 300 DArT markers for the wheat accessions.
dataset_format: A list of three elements.
dataset_reference: Wang, D., list("et al.") (2012) Prediction of genetic values of quantitative traits with epistatic effects in plant breeding populations. list("Heredity") , 109: 313-319.

dataset_title: Create An list("amData") Object That Pairs Datasets With Associated Metadata
dataset_description: Creates an object of class list(list("amData")) , which is typically a data frame of covariate data or model fitting data, with mandatory metadata. It is worth noting that some models include the data as part of the fitted model object, e.g. list("lm") and list("glm") , which access embedded data with list("model.frame") . For large datasets that are embedded in the model, it may be worth documenting metadata a placeholder object such as the character string list("\"embedded data\"") rather than a redundant data object. An S4 class to store data with descriptive metadata.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Methods For Displaying, Summarizing, And Manipulating list("amModelLib") Objects
dataset_description: Methods For Displaying, Summarizing, And Manipulating list("amModelLib") Objects
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Create An list("AMModelLib") Object That Stores Lists Of list("amModel") And list("amData") Objects
dataset_description: Creates an object of class list("amModelLib") , either empty, or containing list(list("amModel")) and/or list(list("amData")) objects. An S4 class to hold model and data, each with descriptive metadata.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Create An list("amModel") Object That Pairs Models With Their Metadata
dataset_description: Creates an object of class list(list("amModel")) , which is a fitted model object (or similar) with mandatory metadata. An S4 class to store models with descriptive metadata.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: SSU Amplicon Frequencies Of Different Sampling Sites (Short Version)
dataset_description: A data frame with 16 amplicon data sets taken from 8 different sampling sites. A reduced version (frequencies of 2500 amplicons) of the list(list("ampliconfreqs.long")) data provided with this package. Samples from each sampling site were sequenced twice, corresponding to sets A and B (e.g. column  FU25.A and FU25.B). Names of the sampling sites are specified in the data list(list("site.f")) .

dataset_title: Statistical Analysis Of Amplicon Data Of The Same Sample To Identify Artefacts
dataset_description: Increasingly powerful techniques for high-throughput sequencing open the possibility to comprehensively characterize microbial communities, including rare species. However, a still unresolved issue are the substantial error rates in the experimental process generating these sequences. To overcome these limitations we propose an approach, where each sample is split and the same amplification and sequencing protocol is applied to both halves. This procedure should allow to detect likely PCR and sequencing artifacts, and true rare species by comparison of the results of both parts. The list("AmpliconDuo") package, whereas ampliconduo from here on refers to the two amplicon data sets of a split sample, is intended to help interpret the obtained amplicon frequency distribution across split samples, and to filter the false positive amplicons.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Lange A, Jost S, Heider D, Bock C, Budeus B, Schilling E, Strittmatter A, Boenigk J, Hoffmann D: AmpliconDuo: A Split-Sample Filtering Protocol for High-Throughput Amplicon Sequencing of Microbial Communities. list("(PLoS One. 2015 Nov 2;10(11))")

dataset_title: Random forest model of amyloid proteins
dataset_description: Random forest grown using the list("ranger") package with additional information.
dataset_format: A list of length three: random forest, a vector of important n-grams and the best-performing encoding.

dataset_description: Amyloids are proteins associated with the number of clinical disorders (e.g., Alzheimer's, Creutzfeldt-Jakob's and Huntington's diseases). Despite their diversity, all amyloid proteins can undergo aggregation initiated by 6- to 15-residue segments called hot spots. Henceforth, amyloids form unique, zipper-like beta-structures, which are often harmful. To find the patterns defining the hot spots, we developed our novel predictor of amyloidogenicity AmyloGram, based on random forests.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Burdukiewicz MJ, Sobczyk P, Roediger S, Duda-Madej A, Mackiewicz P, Kotulska M. (2016) list("Prediction of amyloidogenicity\n", "based on the n-gram analysis") . PeerJ Preprints 4:e2390v1 list("https://doi.org/10.7287/peerj.preprints.2390v1")

dataset_description: This data set is a hypothetical data set originally contrived by Maxwell (1961) for demonstrating his method of discriminant analysis. The data consist of three criterion groups, schizophrenic , manic-depressive and anxiety state, and four binary predictor variables each indicating either presence (1) or absence (0) of a certain symptom. The four symptoms are anxiety suspicion, schizophrenic type of thought disorders, and delusions of guilt. These four binary variables were factorially combined to form 16 distinct patterns of symptoms (predictor patterns), and each of these patterns is identified with a row of the table, which contains the cross-classification of 620 patients according to the 16 patterns of symptoms and the three criterion groups.
dataset_format: A list with the frequency table as the first element and the row covariates as the second.
dataset_reference: Maxwell, A.E. (1961). Canonical variate analysis when the variables are dichotomous. Educational and Psychological Measurement, 21,259-271.

dataset_description: The classic pollen data set from Abernethy Forest in the Scottish highlands, UK. The data originate from the work of Hilary Birks and Rolf Mathewes (1978) and have been analysed in several texts on quantitative numerical palaeoecology. The data set consists of 36 pollen taxa from 49 levels, with two additional variables; list("Age") , the age of each sample, and list("Depth") the depth (in cm) below the surface of the peat sequence from which the core was taken.
dataset_format: list("abernethy") is a data frame with 49 samples on 36 species plus sample Age and Depth (in cm).
dataset_source: These data were provided in electronic format by Prof. H. John B. Birks. The original source is Birks and Mathewes (1978).
dataset_reference: Birks, H.H. and Mathewes, R.W. (1978) Studies in the vegetational history of Scotland. list("New Phytologist") list("80") , 455-484.

dataset_description: An example data set for paired data analysis. A dataframe with the normalized Spleen data set as used in the original article.
dataset_format: spleen is a dataframe. The first column contains gene names. The 6 columns A.1 to A.6 contain normalized mean log-intensity and the 6 columns M.1 to M.6 correspond to normalized log-ratio
dataset_reference: P. Delmar, Robin, S., Tronik-Le Roux S. and Daudin J.-J. (2005) Mixture model on the variance for the differential analysis of gene expression data, JRSS series C, 54(1), 31:50

dataset_description: An exemple data set for unpaired data analysis. A dataframe with the normalized Apo data set as used in the original article.
dataset_format: apo is a dataframe. The first column contains gene names. The 8 columns cond1.1 to cond1.8 contain normalized normal mice measurements and the 8 columns cond2.1 to cond2.8 correspond to normalized KO mice measurements
dataset_reference: M.J. Callow, S. Dudoit, E.L. Gong, T.P. Speed, and E.M. Rubin. Microarray expression profiling identifies genes with altered expression in hdl-deficien mice. Genome Res., 10(12) : 2022-9, 2000

dataset_description: This package contains functions for normalisation,differentially analysis of microarray data and others functions implementing recent methods developed by the Statistic and Genom Team from UMR 518 AgroParisTech/INRA Appl. Math. Comput. Sc.

dataset_title: Allele Variants for Demo SNPs According to dbSNP.
dataset_description: This data set contains the major and minor alleles for the 1000 SNPs used in the demo data according to the strand orientation used on dbSNP.
dataset_format: A matrix containing 1000 observations of two variables.

dataset_title: Object each reference file is assigned as it is loaded in or read.
dataset_description: arithmeticRefsMedoids is the name of the object each reference is assigned to after it is loaded or read.
dataset_format: A list of two character vectors, the first containing the name of each SNP and the second containing the arithmetic medoid value for each SNP.
dataset_source: Ancestry Mapper from various datasets. See: http://bit.ly/1OUstDP

dataset_description: Package computes the genetic distance, defined as the euclidean distance amongst a sample set of individuals and any number of human population references. The package allows for the visualisation of the relationship of sample individuals to the reference populations, thus permitting the user to assess the relationship of individuals to different geographic groupings. Package comes with pre-loaded with toy data and toy references from various sources comprising 158 global populations. Additional and full  Population References can be downloaded from: http://bit.ly/1OUstDP
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Magalh\~aes et al, 2012 PLOS One accepted.

dataset_title: Demographic Data From 2004 American National Election Studies (ANES)
dataset_description: A dataset containing demographic data from the 2004 American National Election Studies.  The data include 5 variables: "female" (A Logical Variable Indicating Sex), "age" (Numerically Coded, Ranging From 18 to a Topcode of 90), "educats" (5 Education Categories corresponding to 1-Less than A High School Degree, 2-High School Gradutate, 3-Some College, 4-College Graduate, 5-Post College Education), "racecats" (6 Racial Categories), and "married" (A Logical Variable Indicating the Respondent's Marital Status, with one point of missing data).  Dataset is designed show how production of survey weights works in practice.
dataset_format: The format is: chr "anes04"

dataset_title: Anfis' trained example to use for demonstration
dataset_description: The example consist in learning of a bidimentional sinc(x,y) function using a regular grid of 121 points in the domain [-10,10]x[-10,10] and five independent Normalized Gaussian Membership Function (MF) for each input (x and y). The training process used the Hybrid off-line Jang's strategy for 10 epochs.
dataset_format: An ANFIS trained object for demonstration.

", "    ", list(list(list("second")), list("a numeric vector")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("mx_raw")), list("a numeric vector. Magnetometer x-axis value in bits")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("my_raw")), list("a numeric vector. Magnetometer y-axis value in bits")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("mz_raw")), list("a numeric vector. Magnetometer z-axis value in bits")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("ax_raw")), list("a numeric vector. Accelerometer x-axis value in bits")), "

dataset_title: Yaw, pitch, and roll simulation data.
dataset_description: Simulated calibration sequence with 2 yaw, 2 pitch, and 2 roll rotations. No magnetic inclination is assumed. The yaw rotation is clockwise, with the x-axis facing north at the beginning and end of the rotations. The pitch rotation is a downward pitch with the x-axis facing north at the beginning. The roll rotation is a downward rotation with the x-axis facing west at the beginning.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 378 observations on the following 11 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("mx")), list("a numeric vector of magnetometer X-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("my")), list("a numeric vector of magnetometer Y-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("mz")), list("a numeric vector of magnetometer Z-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("ax")), list("a numeric vector of accelerometer X-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("ay")), list("a numeric vector of accelerometer Y-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(
    list(list("az")), list("a numeric vector of accelerometer Z-axis values.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("pitch")), list("pitch values (in radians from ", list(list("-\pi/2 \le")), " to ", list(list("\le \pi/2")), ")")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("roll")), list("roll values (in radians from ", list(list("-\pi \le")), " to ", list(list("\le \pi")), ")")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("heading")), list("heading values (in radians from ", list(list("0")), " to ", list(list("2\pi")), 
    ")")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("xh")), list("tilt corrected X-axis magnetometer values (in radians)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("yh")), list("tilt corrected Y-axis magnetometer values (in radians)")), "
", "  ")

",

dataset_source: Simulated data set based on the clinical study reported by: Yusuf, S. et al. (1991). Effect of Enalapril on Survival in Patients with Reduced Left-Ventricular Ejection Fractions and Congestive-Heart-Failure. list("NEJM") 325:293-302.

dataset_title: Prognostic response plot (PR-plot) for list("anoint") class.
dataset_description: Computes the prognostic score (baseline risk) based on the covariates of list("anoint") or a supplied set of predictions. Risk scores are binned into ten groups based on risk deciles and a treatment effect (and confidence interval) is estimated in each group. This is compared to the overall treatment effect which is indicated by the shaded region.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: Fits one-by-one (OBO), unrestricted (UIM), and proportional interaction (PIM) regression models to investigate multiple treatment response factors in a parallel-group clinical trial.

dataset_title: Landmarks of the sampled women of the Spanish Survey
dataset_description:
The body shape of the women who belong to list(list("sampleSpanishSurvey")) is represented by a set of anatomical correspondence points, called landmarks. This database collects the set of landmarks of each woman. The landmarks considered were placed in three different ways: list("
", list(), " Automatic landmarks: automatically calculated with scanner program algorithms, based on geometrical features of the body.
", " 
", list(), " Manual landmarks: points which are not reflected on the external body geometry; they were located through palpation by expert personnel and identified by a physical marker.
", " 
", list(), " Digital landmarks: detected on the computer screen in the 3D scanned image. They are not robust on the automatic calculation but are easy to detect on the screen.  
")
dataset_format: A data frame with 600 observations and 198 variables (66 landmarks times 3 dimensions).
dataset_source: Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population.
dataset_reference: Vinue, G., Simo, A., and Alemany, S., (2014). The k-means algorithm for 3D shapes with an application to apparel design, list("Advances in Data Analysis and Classification") , 1--30. Alemany, S., Gonzalez, J. C., Nacher, B., Soriano, C., Arnaiz, C., and Heras, H., (2010). Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population aimed at the apparel industry. list("Proceedings of the 2010 Intl. Conference on 3D Body scanning Technologies") , 307--315.

dataset_description: This data set comes from the 1967 United States Air Force (USAF) survey (available from list("http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/") ). The 1967 USAF survey was conducted during the first three months of 1967 under the direction of the Anthropology Branch of the Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory, located in Ohio. Subjects were measured at 17 Air Force bases across the United States of America. A total of 202 variables (including body dimensions and background variables) were taken on 2420 Air Force personnel between 21 and 50 years of age. Please find in www.uv.es/vivigui/softw/data_information.zip some files that provide a detailed information about this database. Please note that in this documentation 24 variable names are excluded (Vars 9-11, 28, 76-95). As a complement of this, a report which lists all the variables can be downloaded from list("http://www.dtic.mil/docs/citations/ADA047314") . In Epifanio et al. (2013), the column numbers selected were c(48,40,39,33,32) and correspond to 'Thumb tip reach', 'Buttock-Knee length', 'Popliteal height sitting', 'Sitting height', 'Eye height sitting' and 'Shoulder height sitting'.
dataset_format: A matrix with 2420 rows and 202 columns. Each row corresponds to an observation, and each column corresponds to a variable.
dataset_reference: Vinue, G., Epifanio, I., and Alemany, S., (2015). Archetypoids: a new approach to define representative archetypal data, list("Computational Statistics and Data Analysis") list("87") , 102--115. Epifanio, I., Vinue, G., and Alemany, S., (2013). Archetypal analysis: contributions for estimating boundary cases in multivariate accommodation problem, list("Computers & Industrial Engineering") list("64") , 757--765.

dataset_title: Description of the dissimilarities between women's trunks
dataset_description: Unlike archetypes, archetypoids can be computed when features are unavailable. Given a dissimilarity matrix, the classical multidimensional scaling (cMDS) can be applied to obtain a description of the dissimilarities. In Vinue et al. (2015), the dissimilarity matrix represents the dissimilarities between women's trunks. After applying the cMDS, the database described here is obtained. Then, the archetypoid algorithm can be applied to this database, see section list("examples") .
dataset_format: A matrix with 470 rows and 4 columns.
dataset_source: Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population.
dataset_reference: Vinue, G., Epifanio, I., and Alemany, S., (2015). Archetypoids: a new approach to define representative archetypal data, list("Computational Statistics and Data Analysis") list("87") , 102--115. Alemany, S., Gonzalez, J. C., Nacher, B., Soriano, C., Arnaiz, C., and Heras, H., (2010). Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population aimed at the apparel industry. list("Proceedings of the 2010 Intl. Conference on 3D Body scanning Technologies") , 307--315.

dataset_title: Sample database of the Spanish anthropometric survey
dataset_description: This a database for academic and training purposes. It is oriented to exemplify the use of list(list("trimowa")) , list(list("hipamAnthropom")) and list(list("TDDclust")) . It is made up of 600 women selected randomly from the Spanish anthropometric survey and five anthropometric variables: chest circumference, neck to ground length, waist circumference, hip circumference and bust circumference. These variables have been chosen following the recommendations of experts. In addition, they are commonly used in the literature about sizing system design and they appear in the European standard to sizing system.
dataset_format: A matrix with 600 rows and 5 columns. Each row corresponds to an observation, and each column corresponds to a variable.
dataset_source: Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population.
dataset_reference: Alemany, S., Gonzalez, J. C., Nacher, B., Soriano, C., Arnaiz, C., and Heras, H., (2010). Anthropometric survey of the Spanish female population aimed at the apparel industry. list("Proceedings of the 2010 Intl. Conference on 3D Body scanning Technologies") , 307--315. Ibanez, M. V., Vinue, G., Alemany, S., Simo, A., Epifanio, I., Domingo, J., and Ayala, G., (2012). Apparel sizing using trimmed PAM and OWA operators, list("Expert Systems with Applications") list("39") , 10512--10520. Vinue, G., Leon, T., Alemany, S., and Ayala, G., (2013). Looking for representative fit models for apparel sizing, list("Decision Support Systems") list("57") , 22--33. Vinue, G., Epifanio, I., and Alemany, S., (2015). Archetypoids: a new approach to define representative archetypal data, list("Computational Statistics and Data Analysis") list("87") , 102--115. Vinue, G., Simo, A., and Alemany, S., (2014). dataset_description: Anthropometry brings together some statistical methodologies especially developed to analyze anthropometric data. These methods are aimed at providing effective solutions to some commons problems related to Ergonomics and Anthropometry. They are based on clustering, the statistical concept of data depth, statistical shape analysis and archetypal analysis.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Vinue, G., (2017). Anthropometry: An R Package for Analysis of Anthropometric Data, list("Journal of Statistical Software") list("77(6)") , 1--40, doi:10.18637/jss.v077.i06

dataset_description: Experimental data for analyzing the effect of an increasing dose of a compound on the proportion of live foetuses affected. dataset_title: Age, Period and Cohort Effects for Vital Rates
dataset_description: Number of prostate cancer deaths and midperiod population for nonwhites in the USA by age and period. The cohort index list(list("k")) is related to age and period indices ( list(list("i")) and list(list("j")) , respectively) by list(list("k = j + I - i")) , where list(list("I = max(i)")) (Holford, 1983, Table 2).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 49 observations on the following 4 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("period"), list("A factor with levels ", list("1935-"), ", ", list("1940-"), ", ", list(), ", ", list("1965-"), ".")), "
", "    ", list(list("age"), list("A factor with levels ", list("50-"), ", ", list("55-"), ", ", list(), ", ", list("80-"), ".")), "
", "    ", list(list("y"), list("Numeric: the number of prostate cancer deaths.")), "
", "    ", list(list("n"), list("Numeric: the midperiod population size.")), "
", "    ")
dataset_reference: Holford, T.R., 1983. list("The estimation of age, period and cohort effects for vital rates") . Biometrics 39, 311-324.

dataset_title: A Comparison of Site Preferences of Two Species of Lizard
dataset_description:
list("These data describe the daytime habits of two species of lizards, ", list("grahami"), " and ", list("opalinus"), ". 
", "  They were collected by observing occupied sites or perches and recording the appropriate description, namely 
", "  species involved, time of the day, height and diameter of the perch and whether the site was sunny or shaded. 
", "  Time of the day is recorded as early, mid-day or late.") (McCullagh and Nelder, 1989, p.129).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 24 observations on the following 6 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("Site"), list("A factor with levels ", list("Sun"), " and ", list("Shade"), ".")), "
", "    ", list(list("Diameter"), list("A factor with levels ", list("D <= 2"), " and ", list("D > 2"), " (inches). ")), "
", "    ", list(list("Height"), list("A factor with levels ", list("H < 5"), " and ", list("H >= 5"), " (feet).")), "
", "    ", list(list("Time"), list("A factor with levels ", list("Early"), ", ", list("Mid-day"), " and ", list("Late"), ".")), "
", "    ", list(
    list("grahami"), list("A numeric vector giving the observed sample size for ", list("grahami"), " lizards.")), "
", "    ", list(list("opalinus"), list("A numeric vector giving the observed sample size for ", list("opalinus"), " lizards.")), "
", "    ")
dataset_source: McCullagh, P., Nelder, J.A., 1989. list("Generalized linear models") . London, Chapman & Hall, 511 p.
dataset_reference: Fienberg, S.E., 1970. list("The analysis of multidimensional contingency tables") . Ecology 51: 419-433.

dataset_description:
list("Weil (1970) in Table 1 gives the results from an experiment comprising two treatments. One group of

", "  of pups that survived the 21 day lactation period were recorded.") (Williams, 1975, p. 951).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 32 observations on the following 3 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("group"), list("A factor with levels ", list("CTRL"), " and ", list("TREAT"))), "
", "    ", list(list("n"), list("A numeric vector: the number of pups alive at 4 days.")), "

dataset_title: Mortality of Djallonke Lambs in Senegal
dataset_description: Field trial to assess the effect of ewes deworming (prevention of gastro-intestinal parasitism) on the mortality of their offspring (age < 1 year). This data set is extracted from a large database on small ruminants production and health in Senegal (Lancelot et al., 1998). Data were collected in a sample of herds in Kolda (Upper Casamance, Senegal) during a multi-site survey (Faugère et al., 1992). See also the references below for a presentation of the follow-up survey (Faugère and Faugère, 1986) and a description of the farming systems (Faugère et al., 1990).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 21 observations on the following 4 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("group"), list("a factor with 2 levels: ", list("CTRL"), " and ", list("TREAT"), ", indicating the treatment.")), "
", "    ", list(list("village"), list("a factor indicating the village of the herd.")), "
", "    ", list(list("herd"), list("a factor indicating the herd.")), "
", "    ", list(list("n"), list("a numeric vector: the number of animals exposed to mortality.")), "
", "    ", list(list("trisk"), list("a numeric vector: the exposition time to mortality (in year).")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list("y"), list("a numeric vector: the number of deaths.")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference:
Faugère, O., Faugère, B., 1986. list("Suivi de troupeaux et contrôle des performances individuelles des petits
", "  ruminants en milieu traditionnel africain. Aspects méthodologiques.") Rev. Elev. Méd. vét. Pays trop., 39 (1): 29-40. list() Faugère, O., Dockès, A.-C., Perrot, C., Faugère, B., 1990. list("L'élevage traditionnel des petits ruminants
", "  au Sénégal. I. Pratiques de conduite et d'exploitation des animaux chez les éleveurs de la région de Kolda.") Revue Elev. Méd. vét. Pays trop. 43: 249-259. Faugère, O., Tillard, E., Faugère, B., 1992. list("Prophylaxie chez les petits ruminants au Sénégal : régionalisation
", "  d'une politique nationale de protection sanitaire") . In: B. Rey, S. H. B. Lebbie, L. Reynolds (Ed.), First biennial conference of the African Small Ruminant Research Network, ILCA, 1990, ILRAD, Nairobi, pp. 307-314. Lancelot, R., Faye, B., Juanès, X., Ndiaye, M., Pérochon, L., Tillard, E., 1998. list("La base de données BAOBAB:
", "  un outil pour modéliser la production et la santé des petits ruminants dans les systèmes d'élevage traditionnels
", "  au Sénégal.") Revue Elev. Méd. vét. Pays trop., 51 (2): 135-146.

dataset_description: This package provides a set of functions to analyse overdispersed counts or proportions. Most of the methods are already available elsewhere but are scattered in different packages. The proposed functions should be considered as complements to more sophisticated methods such as generalized estimating equations (GEE) or generalized linear mixed effect models (GLMM).
dataset_format: NA

dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: The Abalone data consist of data from 4177 abalones. The data consist of measurements of the type (male, female and infant), the longest shell measurement, the diameter, height and several weights (whole, shucked, viscera and shell). The outcome is the number of rings. The age of the abalone is the number of rings plus 1.5. The data are taken from the UCI database ( list("http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Abalone") ).
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: add some notes
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: These data consist of information on 4331 jobs in a high performance computing environment. Seven attributes were recorded for each job along with a discrete class describing the execution time. The predictors are: list("Protocol") (the type of computation), list("Compounds") (the number of data points for each jobs), list("InputFields") (the number of characteristic being estimated), list("Iterations") (maximum number of iterations for the computations), list("NumPending") (the number of other jobs pending at the time of launch), list("Hour") (decimal hour of day for launch time) and list("Day") (of launch time). The classes are: list("VF") (very fast), list("F") (fast), list("M") (moderate) and list("L") (long).
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: Hill, LaPan, Li and Haney (2007) develop models to predict which cells in a high content screen were well segmented. The data consists of 119 imaging measurements on 2019. The original analysis used 1009 for training and 1010 as a test set (see the column called list("Case") ). The outcome class is contained in a factor variable called list("Class") with levels "PS" for poorly segmented and "WS" for well segmented. A pre-processed version of these data can be found in the list("caret") package.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_source: Hill, LaPan, Li and Haney (2007). Impact of image segmentation on high-content screening data quality for SK-BR-3 cells, list("BMC Bioinformatics") , Vol. 8, pg. 340, list("http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/8/340") .

dataset_title: Compressive Strength of Concrete from Yeh (1998)
dataset_description: Yeh (1998) describes a collection of data sets from different sources that can be used for modeling the compressive strength of concrete formulations as a functions of their ingredients and age.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_source: Yeh, I. C. (1998). Modeling of strength of high-performance concrete using artificial neural networks. list("Cement and Concrete Research") , 28(12), 1797-1808. Elsevier.

dataset_description: Washington University conducted a clinical study to determine if biological measurements made from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be used to diagnose or predict Alzheimer's disease (Craig-Schapiro et al. 2011). These data are a modified version of the values used for the publication. The R factor vector list("diagnosis") contains the outcome data for 333 of the subjects. The demographic and laboratory results are collected in the data frame list("predictors") . One important indicator of Alzheimer's disease is the genetic background of a subject. In particular, what versions of the Apolipoprotein E gene inherited from one's parents has an association with the disease. There are three variants of the gene: E2, E3 and E4. Since a child inherits a version of the gene from each parent, there are six possible combinations (e.g. E2/E2, E2/E3, and so on). This data is contained in the predictor column named list("Genotype")
dataset_format: NA
dataset_source: Craig-Schapiro, R., Kuhn, M., Xiong, C., Pickering, E. H., Liu, J., Misko, T. P., Perrin, R. J., et al. (2011). Multiplexed Immunoassay Panel Identifies Novel CSF Biomarkers for Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis and Prognosis. PLoS ONE, 6(4), e18850.

dataset_description: This package can be used to reproduce the analyses in the text. Scripts for each chapter are located in the "chapters" directory. Use list("scriptLocation()") to find their exact location.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Kuhn M and Johnson K (2013) Applied Predictive Modeling, Springer, NY

dataset_description: This data set contains information about a chemical manufacturing process, in which the goal is to understand the relationship between the process and the resulting final product yield.  Raw material in this process is put through a sequence of 27 steps to generate the final pharmaceutical product.  The starting material is generated from a biological unit and has a range of quality and characteristics.  The objective in this project was to develop a model to predict percent yield of the manufacturing process.  The data set consisted of 177 samples of biological material for which 57 characteristics were measured.  Of the 57 characteristics, there were 12 measurements of the biological starting material, and 45 measurements of the manufacturing process.  The process variables included measurements such as temperature, drying time, washing time, and concentrations of by--products at various steps.  Some of the process measurements can be controlled, while others are observed.  Predictors are continuous, count, categorical; some are correlated, and some contain missing values.  Samples are not independent because sets of samples come from the same batch of biological starting material.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This  data set was used to develop a model for predicting compounds' probability of causing hepatic injury (i.e. liver damage). This data set consisted of 281 unique compounds; 376 predictors were measured or computed for each. The response was categorical (either "None", "Mild" or "Severe" ),and was highly unbalanced. This kind of response often occurs in pharmaceutical data because companies steer away from creating molecules that have undesirable characteristics. Therefore, well-behaved molecules often greatly outnumber undesirable molecules. The predictors consisted of measurements from 184 biological screens and 192 chemical feature predictors. The biological predictors represent activity for each screen and take values between 0 and 10 with a mode of 4. The chemical feature predictors represent counts of important sub-structures as well as measures of physical properties that are thought to be associated with hepatic injury.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: The list("http://fueleconomy.gov") website, run by the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, lists different estimates of fuel economy for passenger cars and trucks. For each vehicle, various characteristics are recorded such as the engine displacement or number of cylinders. Along with these values, laboratory measurements are made for the city and highway miles per gallon (MPG) of the car. Predictors extracted from the website include: list("EngDispl") , list("NumCyl") list("Transmission") list("AirAspirationMethod") list("NumGears") list("TransLockup") list("TransCreeperGear") list("DriveDesc") list("IntakeValvePerCyl") list("ExhaustValvesPerCyl") list("CarlineClassDesc") list("VarValveTiming") and list("VarValveLift") . The outcome used in the book is in column list("FE") and is the unadjusted highway data.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: Tetko et al. (2001) and Huuskonen (2000) investigated a set of compounds with corresponding experimental solubility values using complex sets of descriptors. They used linear regression and neural network models to estimate the relationship between chemical structure and solubility. For our analyses, we will use 1267 compounds and a set of more understandable descriptors that fall into one of three groups: 208 binary "fingerprints" that indicate the presence or absence of a particular chemical sub-structure, 16 count descriptors (such as the number of bonds or the number of Bromine atoms) and 4 continuous descriptors (such as molecular weight or surface area).
dataset_format: NA
dataset_source: Tetko, I., Tanchuk, V., Kasheva, T., and Villa, A. (2001). Estimation of aqueous solubility of chemical compounds using E-state indices. list("Journal of Chemical Information and Computer Sciences") , 41(6), 1488-1493. Huuskonen, J. (2000). Estimation of aqueous solubility for a diverse set of organic compounds based on molecular topology. , 40(3), 773-777.

dataset_description: This pharmaceutical data set was used to develop a model for predicting compounds' permeability.  In short, permeability is the measure of a molecule's ability to cross a membrane.  The body, for example, has notable membranes between the body and brain, known as the blood-brain barrier, and between the gut and body in the intestines.  These membranes help the body guard critical regions from receiving undesirable or detrimental substances.  For an orally taken drug to be effective in the brain, it first must pass through the intestinal wall and then must pass through the blood-brain barrier in order to be present for the desired neurological target.  Therefore, a compound's ability to permeate relevant biological membranes is critically important to understand early in the drug discovery process.  Compounds that appear to be effective for a particular disease in research screening experiments, but appear to be poorly permeable may need to be altered in order improve permeability, and thus the compound's ability to reach the desired target.  Identifying permeability problems can help guide chemists towards better molecules. Permeability assays such as PAMPA and Caco-2 have been developed to help measure compounds' permeability (Kansy et al, 1998).  These screens are effective at quantifying a compound's permeability, but the assay is expensive labor intensive.  Given a sufficient number of compounds that have been screened, we could develop a predictive model for permeability in an attempt to potentially reduce the need for the assay.  In this project there were 165 unique compounds; 1107 molecular fingerprints were determined for each.  A molecular fingerprint is a binary sequence of numbers that represents the presence or absence of a specific molecular sub-structure.  The response is highly skewed, the predictors are sparse (15.5 percent are present), and many predictors are strongly associated.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_source: Kansy, M., Senner, F., and Gubernator, K. (1998). Physicochemical High Throughput Screening:  Parallel Artificial Membrane Permeation Assay in the Description of Passive Absorption Processes. J. Med. Chem, 41(7), 1007-1010.

dataset_description: Genie datasets that illustrate the package.
dataset_format: The genie example is a case with three levels. The list("D1.genie") matrix is 36 rows of code run points, corresponding to the observations of the level 1 code.  It has four columns, one per parameter. list("hpa.genie") is a hyperparameter object. list("subsets.genie") is a list of three elements.  Element list(list("i")) corresponds to the rows of at which level has been observed. list("z.genie") is a three element list.  Each element is a vector; element corresponds to observations of level .  The lengths will match those of . Function list("basis.genie()") is a suitable basis function. list("hpa.fun.genie()") creates a hyperparameter object in a form suitable for passing to the other functions in the library.
dataset_reference: M. C. Kennedy and A. O'Hagan 2000. list("Predicting the output from\n", "    a complex computer code when fast approximations are available") Biometrika, 87(1): pp1-13

O'Hagan 2000. list("Predicting the output from\n", "    a complex computer code when fast approximations are available") Biometrika, 87(1): pp1-13

dataset_description: Toy datasets that illustrate the package.

It is a list of three elements: list("sigmas") , list("B") , and list("rhos") . list("subsets.toy") is a list of four elements.  Element list(list("i")) corresponds to the rows of at which level has been observed. list("z.toy") is a four element list.  Each element is a vector; element corresponds to obsevations of level .  The lengths will match those of list("betas.toy") is a matrix of coefficients. list("Brief description of toy functions fully documented under their own manpage") Function list("generate.toy.observations()") creates new toy datasets with any number of observations and code runs. list("basis.toy()") is an example of a basis function list("hpa.fun.toy()") creates a hyperparameter object such as list("phi.toy") in a form suitable for passing to the other functions in the library. list("See the helpfiles listed in the ", list("see also"), " section\n", "  below")

dataset_title: Functions to estimate Average Positive Predictive Values (AP) for Binary Outcomes and Censored Event.
dataset_description: We provide tools to estimate two prediction performance metrics, AP and AUC for risk scores or marker. The outcome of interest is either binary or censored event time. Note that for censored event time, the AP and the AUC are time-dependent for pre-specified time interval(s). A function that compares the APs of two risk scores/markers is also included. Optional outputs include positive predictive values and true positive fractions at the specified marker cut-off values, and a plot of the time-dependent AP versus time (available for event time data).
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: The aqp (Algorithms for Quantitative Pedology) package for R was developed to address some of the difficulties associated with processing soils information, specifically related to visualization, aggregation, and classification of soil profile data. This package is based on a mix of S3/S4 functions and classes, and most functions use basic dataframes as input, where rows represent soil horizons and columns define properties of those horizons. Common to most functions are the requirements that horizon boundaries are defined as depth from 0, and that profiles are uniquely defined by an id column. The aqp package defines an S4 class, "SoilProfileCollection", for storage of profile-level metadata, as well as summary, print, and plotting methods that have been customized for common tasks related to soils data. Demos: list("demo(aqp)") list("demo(slope_effect_hz_thickness)") Extended Examples: list(list("http://casoilresource.lawr.ucdavis.edu/drupal/taxonomy/term/56"), list("AQP-related blog posts")) list(list("https://r-forge.r-project.org/scm/viewvc.php/*checkout*/docs/aqp/aqp-intro.html?root=aqp"), list("Introduction to SoilProfileCollection objects")) list(list("https://r-forge.r-project.org/scm/viewvc.php/*checkout*/docs/aqp/aqp-profile-dissimilarity.html?root=aqp"), list("Soil profile dissimilarity demo")) list(list("https://r-forge.r-project.org/scm/viewvc.php/*checkout*/docs/aqp/vertical_vs_perpendicular.html?root=aqp"), list("Vertical vs. perpendicular horizon depth measurement demo"))
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: Vector of size 1600 which is a piecewise constant function corrupted by a Gaussian AR(1) process with rho=0.3 and where the standard deviation of the innovation process is equal to 0.1. The piecewise constant function has its breaks at the following positions: 222, 311, 711, 888, 1200, 1466 and takes the following values: 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 on each associated segment.

dataset_title: Segmentation of an AR(1) Gaussian process
dataset_description: This package consists in an implementation of a robust approach to solve the problem of multiple change-point estimation in the mean of a Gaussian AR(1) process. A robust estimator of the autoregression parameter is proposed and used to build a decorrelated series on which a classical penalized least-square approach is applied.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: S. Chakar, E. Lebarbier, C. Levy-Leduc, S. Robin. A robust approach to multiple change-point estimation in an AR(1) process, arXiv:1403.1958.

The phosphorus concentration measurement was subject to a limit of detection (lcl), thereby the P data are left censored. The water discharge dataset were obtained from the website of U.S. Geological Survey (site number 05458900), and it is measured in cubic feet per second.

dataset_title: Ksar Akil chronology build with ChronoModel software. Phases part.
dataset_description: MCMC samples from the posterior distribution of dates included in the Ksar Akil chronology build with ChronoModel software. The MCMC samples are in calendar year (BC/AD).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 30000 observations on the following 9 variables, two variables for each group of dates and the MCMC iteration number. These four phases are in stratigraphic order, the order from the oldest to the youngest phase being : IUP, Ahmarian, UP and EPI.These observations come from 3 parallel chains. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("iter")), list("a numeric vector corresponding to iteration number")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("EPI.alpha")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the minimum of the phase "EPI". ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("EPI.beta")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the maximum of the phase "EPI". ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("UP.alpha")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the the minimum of the phase "UP". ")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("UP.beta")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the maximum of the phase "UP".")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Ahmarian.alpha")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the the minimum of the phase "Ahmarian". ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Ahmarian.beta")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the maximum of the phase "Ahmarian".")), "
", "    ", list(
        list(list("IUP.alpha")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the minimum of the phase "IUP". ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("IUP.beta")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the maximum of the phase "IUP". ")), "
", "  ")

dataset_reference: Lanos, P. et al. (2016) Chronomodel  : Chronological Modelling of Archaeological Data using Bayesian Statistics (Version 1.5). www.chronomodel.fr Vibet. M.-A. et al. (2016) ChronoModel V1.5 User's manual.

dataset_title: Ksar Akil chronology build with ChronoModel software. Dates part.
dataset_description: MCMC samples from the posterior distribution of dates included in the Ksar Akil chronology build with ChronoModel software.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 30000 observations on the following 17 variables, one variable per AMS date and the MCMC iteration number. These observations come from 3 parallel chains. The MCMC samples are in calendar year (BC/AD). list("
", "    ", list(list(list("iter")), list("a numeric vector corresponding to iteration number")), "
", "

dataset_title: Polynesian fishpond site on the island of Oahu, Hawaii.
dataset_description: MCMC samples from the posterior distribution of dates estimated by BCal software according to a Polynesian fishpond site on the island of Oahu, Hawaii. The site contains two main layers and 5 radiocarbon dates. See the tutorial of BCal for the details of the modeling.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 55965 observations on the following 12 variables contained in the outputs generated by BCal. The MCMC samples are in format cal BP (before 1950). list("
", "    ", list(list(list("Iteration")), list("a vector corresponding to iteration number. Here it is a non numeric vector as the last value is "EOF".")), "

", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("theta.5..Layer.II.")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date theta.5.")), "
", "    
", 
    "    ", list(list(list("theta.4..Layer.II.")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date theta.4.")), "

", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("theta.2..Layer.II.")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date theta.2.")), "
", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("alpha.2..Layer.II.")), 
        list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date of the start of Layer II. ")), "
", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("beta.1..Layer.III.")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date of the end of Layer III. ")), "
", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("theta.1..Layer.III.")), list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date theta.1.")), "
", "    
", "    ", list(list(list("alpha.1..Layer.III.")), 
        list("a numeric vector containing the output of the MCMC algorithm for the date of the start of Layer III. ")), "

", "    ", list(list(list("X")), list(" vector of NA ")), "

dataset_reference: BCal is an easy to use, on-line Bayesian radiocarbon calibration tool for interpreting radiocarbon data along with expert chronological information. It is hosted by the School of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of Sheffield. See http://bcal.shef.ac.uk/.
