dataset_description: The list("dormicum") data frame has 37 rows and 3 columns. 37 children in a pediatric intensive care unit were treated with varying doses and for varying duration with the drug list("Dormicum") .  The response variable is 1 if withdrawal symptoms were exhibited and 0 otherwise.
dataset_format:
This data frame contains the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("symp")), list("
", "      indicator of the presence of withdrawal symptoms;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("dose")), list("
", "      the drug dose in mg/kg;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("days")), list("
", "      the number of days treated.
", "    ")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: The data were supplied by list("Spadille Biostatistik") , Denmark.
dataset_reference: Mehta, C. R., Patel, N. T. and Senchaudhuri, P. (2000) Efficient Monte Carlo methods for conditional logistic regression. list("J. Amer. Statist. Ass.") , list("95") , 99--108.

dataset_title: AIDS Symptoms and AZT Use Data
dataset_description: The list("aids") data frame has 4 rows and 4 columns. On February 15, 1991, the list(" New York Times") published the results of a study on the presence of AIDS symptoms and AZT use. The data were cross-classified according to the race of the patients.
dataset_format:
This data frame contains the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("yes")), list("
", "      the number of patients with AIDS symptoms;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("no")), list("
", "      the number of patients without AIDS symptoms;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("azt")), list("
", "      an indicator variable for AZT use;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("race")), list("
", "      an indicator variable for the race (", list("w"), "=white, ", list("b"), "=black).
", "    ")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: The data were obtained from the list("New York Times") (2/15/91).

dataset_description: The list("rabbits") data frame has 10 rows and 4 columns. Five different doses of penicillin were administered to rabbits suffering from a streptococci infection and the number of recovering rabbits recorded.  The rabbits are cross-classified according to whether the drug is administered immediately or delayed by an hour and a half.  Interest focuses on whether the delay effects the treatment.
dataset_format:
This data frame contains the following columns: list("

", "    ")), "

dataset_description: The list("fraudulent") data frame has 42 rows and 12 columns. 127 claims arising from automobile accidents in 1989 in Massachusetts (USA).  Each claim was classified as either fraudulent or legitimate by consensus among four independent claims adjusters who examined each case file thoroughly.  An exploratory analysis by Derrig and Weisberg (1993) identified 10 binary indicators, each of which denotes the presence or absence of a potential fraud characteristic in the claim situation.  They fall into three broad groups relating to list("Accident") (AC1, AC9 and AC16), list("Claimant") (CL7 and CL11), and list("Injury") (IJ2, IJ3, IJ4, IJ6 and IJ12).
dataset_format:
This data frame contains the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("r1")), list("
", "      the number of frauds detected;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("r2")), list("
", "      the total number of automobile insurance claims;
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("AC1"), ",", list("AC9"), ",", list("AC16")), list("
", "      potential fraud characteristics pertaining to ", list("Accident"), ".  
", "      The presence of the fraud characteristic is indicated by a 1, the 
", "      absence is indicated by a 0.
", 
    "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("CL7"), ",", list("CL11")), list("
", "      potential fraud characteristics pertaining to ", list("Claimer"), ".  
", "      The presence of the fraud characteristic is indicated by a 1, the 
", "      absence is indicated by a 0.
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("IJ2"), ",", list("IJ3"), ",", list("IJ4"), ",", list("IJ6"), ",", list("IJ12")), list("
", "      potential fraud characteristics pertaining to ", list("Injury"), ".  
", "      The presence of the fraud characteristic is indicated by a 1, the 
", 
    "      absence is indicated by a 0.
", "    ")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: The data were supplied by Dr. Richard Derrig of the Automobile Insurers Bureau of Massachusetts.
dataset_reference: Mehta, C. R., Patel, N. T. and Senchaudhuri, P. (2000) Efficient Monte Carlo methods for conditional logistic regression. list("J. Amer. Statist. Ass.") , list("95") , 99--108. Derrig, R. A. and Weisberg, H. I. (1993).  Quantitative methods for detecting fraudulent automobile bodily injury claims. list("Manuscript.")

It contains the coverage vectors for both strands: fwd (coverage depth on the forward strand) and rev (coverage depth on reverse strand).
dataset_format: A data frame.

dataset_title: Develop ensemble classifiers for condition-dependent operon predictions.
dataset_description: A novel approach for the identification of condition-dependent operons. This R package allows R users to build customized ensemble classifiers that integrate genomic and expression-based features to distinguish operon pairs (OPs) from non-operon pairs (NOPs) in a given RNA-seq based transcriptome profile. The ensemble classifier is then used to re-define the operon information annotated in DOOR and build a condition-dependent operon map that includes putative operons.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Literature or other references for background information

dataset_description: bladderCS is a data frame with 8 variables and 85 observations. Data on recurrences of bladder cancer, used by many people to demonstrate methodology for recurrent event modelling.

A data frame with 85 observations on the following 8 variables. Below a brief description is given for some of these variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("t1"), list("Time to first recurrence/censoring, whichever occurs first.")), "

", "    ", list(list("t2"), list("Time to second recurrence/censoring, whichever occurs first.")), "
", "    ", list(list("e2"), list("Recurrence/censoring indicator (second recurrence=1) for the second time (t2)")), "
", "    ", list(list("t3"), list("Time to recurrence/censoring, whichever occurs first.")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list("e3"), list("Recurrence/censoring indicator (third recurrence=1) for the third time (t3)")), "
", "    ", list(list("t4"), list("Time to fourth recurrence/censoring, whichever occurs first.")), "
", "    ", list(list("e4"), list("Recurrence/censoring indicator (fourth recurrence=1) for the fourth time (t4)")), "
", "    ", "%\item{size}{Size (cm) of largest initial tumour.}", "
", "    ")
dataset_reference: Byar, D. (1980) Veterans administration study of chemoprophylaxis for recurrent stage i bladder tumors: Comparisons of placebo, pyridoxine and topical thiotepa. Bladder Tumors and Other Topics in Urological Oncology, 18:363--370.

dataset_description: gbcsCS is a data frame with 16 variables and 686 observations. Cancer clinical trials are a rich source for examples of applications of methods for the analysis of time to event. Willi Sauerbrei and Patrick Royston have graciously provided us with data obtained from the German Breast Cancer Study Group, which they used to illustrate methods for building prognostic models (Sauerbrei and Royston, 1999). In the main study, a total of 720 patients with primary node positive breast cancer were recruited between July 1984, and December 1989, (see Schmoor, Olschweski and Schumacher M. 1996 and Schumacher et al. (1994)).
dataset_format: A data frame with 686 observations on the following 16 variables. %Below a brief description is given for some of these variables. %\describe{ %\item{rectime}{Time to recurrence/censoring, whichever occurs first.} %\item{censrec}{Recurrence/censoring indicator (recurrence=1, alive=0).} %\item{survtime}{Time to censoring/death, whichever occurs first.} %\item{censdead}{Death/censoring indicator (death=1, alive=0).} %\item{age}{Age in years.} %\item{size}{Tumour size.} %}
dataset_reference: Schmoor, C., Sauerbrei, W. Bastert, G., Schumacher, M. (2000). Role of Isolated Locoregional Recurrence of Breast Cancer: Results of Four Prospective Studies. Journal of Clinical Oncology, 18(8), 1696-1708. Schumacher, M., Bastert, G., Bojar, H., Hiibner, K., Olschewski, M., Sauerbrei, W., Schmoor, C., Beyerle, C., Neumann, R.L.A. and Rauschecker, H.F. for the German Breast Cancer Study Group (GBSG) (1994). A randomized 2 x 2 trial evaluating hormonal treatment and the duration of chemotherapy in node-positive breast cancer patients. Journal of Clinical Oncology, 12, 2086-2093. Hosmer, D.W. and Lemeshow, S. and May, S. (2008). Applied Survival Analysis: Regression Modeling of Time to Event Data: Second Edition, John Wiley and Sons Inc., New York, NY

dataset_title: Chemotherapy for Stage B/C colon cancer.
dataset_description: These are data from one of the first successful trials of adjuvant chemotherapy for colon cancer. Levamisole is a low-toxicity compound previously used to treat worm infestations in animals; 5-FU is a moderately toxic (as these things go) chemotherapy agent.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 929 observations on the following 15 variables. Below a brief description is given for some of these variables. list("
", list(list("time1"), list("Time to recurrence/censoring/death, whichever occurs first.")), "
", list(list("event1"), list("Recurrence/censoring indicator (recurrence=1, alive=0).")), "
", list(list("Stime"), list("Time to censoring/death, whichever occurs first.")), "
", list(list("event"), list("Death/censoring indicator (death=1, alive=0).")), "
", list(list("rx"), list("Treatment - Obs(ervation), Lev(amisole), Lev(amisole)+5-FU.")), "
", list(list("sex"), list("Sex indicator (male=1, female=0).")), 
    "
", list(list("age"), list("Age in years.")), "
", list(list("obstruct"), list("Obstruction of colon by tumour.")), "
", list(list("perfor"), list("Perforation of colon.")), "
", list(list("adhere"), list("Adherence to nearby organs.")), "
", list(list("nodes"), list("Number of lymph nodes with detectable cancer.")), "
", list(list("differ"), list("Differentiation of tumour (1=well, 2=moderate, 3=poor).")), "
", list(list("extent"), list("Extent of local spread (1=submucosa, 2=muscle, 3=serosa,
", 
        "4=contiguous structures).")), "
", list(list("surg"), list("Time from surgery to registration (0=short, 1=long).")), "
", list(list("node4"), list("More than 4 positive lymph nodes.")), "
")
dataset_source: The study is originally described in Laurie (1989).The main report is found in Moertel (1990). This data set is closest to that of the final report in Moertel (1991). A version of the data with less follow-up time was used in the paper by Lin (1994).
dataset_reference: JA Laurie, CG Moertel, TR Fleming, HS Wieand, JE Leigh, J Rubin, GW McCormack, JB Gerstner, JE Krook and J Malliard. Surgical adjuvant therapy of large-bowel carcinoma: An evaluation of levamisole and the combination of levamisole and fluorouracil: The North Central Cancer Treatment Group and the Mayo Clinic. Journal of Clinical Oncology, 7:1447-1456, 1989. DY Lin. Cox regression analysis of multivariate failure time data: the marginal approach. Statistics in Medicine, 13:2233-2247, 1994. CG Moertel, TR Fleming, JS MacDonald, DG Haller, JA Laurie, PJ Goodman, JS Ungerleider, WA Emerson, DC Tormey, JH Glick, MH Veeder and JA Maillard. dataset_title: condSURV: c("\\Sexpr[results=rd,stage=build]{tools:::Rd_package_title(\"#1\")}", "condSURV") list("tools:::Rd_package_title(\"condSURV\")") %A package for nonparametric estimation of the survival functions for ordered multivariate failure time data.
dataset_description: Newly developed methods for the estimation of the conditional survival function are implemented in this package. The condSURV package implements nonparametric and semiparametric estimators for these quantities. The package also implements feasible estimation methods for these quantities conditionally on current or past covariate measures. Other related estimators are also implemented in the package. One of these estimators is the Kaplan-Meier estimator typically assumed to estimate the survival function. A modification of the Kaplan-Meier estimator, based on a preliminary estimation (presmoothing) of the censoring probability for the survival time, given the available information is also implemented.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: L. Meira-Machado, M. Sestelo, and A. Goncalves (2016). Nonparametric estimation of the survival function for ordered multivariate failure time data: a comparative study. Biometrical Journal, 58(3), 623--634.

dataset_title: Foot Measurements for Fourth Grade Children
dataset_description: This data set was collected by the first author in a fourth grade classroom in Ann Arbor, MI, October 1997. We use the shapereg function to make a shape-restricted fit to this data set. "Width" is a continuous response variable, "length" is a continuous predictor variable, and "sex" is a categorical covariate. The constraint is that "width" is increasing with respect to "length".
dataset_format:
A data frame with 39 observations on the following 8 variables. list("

    "

", "  ")

They either ‘1’ = solved or ‘2’ = did not solve the problems. The data is in pattern frequencies table representation (object of class c("data.frame", "Pfreq" )).
dataset_format: A matrix with 4 columns and 8 rows. The last column gives the frequencies for the (response) pattern in column 1:3.
dataset_reference: Lazarsfeld, P. F., & Henry, N. W. (1968). list("Latent structure analysis") . Boston: Houghton Mifflin.

dataset_description: Data used as an example for two-sample CFA in the textbook by Mark Stemmler (2014) taken from Linert (1978, p. 978). The data is in pattern frequencies table representation (object of class c("data.frame", "Pfreq" )).
dataset_format: A data frame (object of class list("c(\"data.frame\", \"Pfreq\")") ) with 4 columns and 12 rows. The last column gives the frequencies for the (response) pattern in column 1:2 of the respective 'Group' given in column 3.
dataset_reference: Lienert, G. A. (1978). list("Verteilungsfreie Methoden in der Biostatistik (Band II)") [Non-parametrical 168 methods in the field of biometrics (Vol. II)]. dataset_description: Data from the classical Linert LSD trial as an example for CFA. The data is in pattern frequencies table representation (object of class c("data.frame", "Pfreq" )).
dataset_format: A data frame (object of class list("c(\"data.frame\", \"Pfreq\")") ) with 4 columns and 8 rows. The last column gives the frequencies for the (response) pattern in column 1:3.
dataset_reference: Lienert, G. A. (1971). Die Konfigurationsfrequenzanalyse: I. Ein neuer Weg zu Typen und Syndromen. list("Zeitschrift für Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie, 19") (2), 99-115.

dataset_description: Data from the Linert suicide example for CFA. The data is in data list representation (each row is one case).
dataset_format: A list("data.frame") with 3 columns (as factors).
dataset_reference: Krauth, J., & Lienert, G. A. (1973). list("Die Konfigurationsfrequenzanalyse (KFA) und ihre Anwendung in Psychologie und Medizin: ein multivariates nichtparametrisches Verfahren zur Aufdeckung von Typen und Syndromen; mit 70 Tabellen") . Freiburg; München: Alber Karl.

dataset_description: data example by Stemmler (2014) p. 26 where list("N") = 56 newborns 'with seizures' = 1 or 'without seizures' = 2 (coded in the in first column named 'A') were tested with an intelligence test while they attended kindergarten. Children’s intelligence was divided into 'average or above' = 1 and 'below average' = 2 (coded in the in second column named 'B'). The third column gives the frequencies of the respective pattern.
dataset_format: A data.frame with 3 columns and 4 rows. The last column gives the frequencies for the observed pattern in column 1:2. The data is in pattern frequencies table representation (object of class c("data.frame", "Pfreq"))
dataset_reference: Stemmler, M. (2014). list("Person-Centered Methods -- Configural Frequency Analysis (CFA) and Other Methods for the Analysis of Contingency Tables") . Cham Heidelberg New York Dordrecht London: Springer.

dataset_title: Configural Frequencies Analysis Using Log-linear Modeling
dataset_description: The package list("confreq") offers some functions for Configural Frequencies Analysis (CFA) proposed by G.A. Lienert as an analysis of types and antitypes of persons or objects grouped according to their characteristic (response) pattern. The core principle in the package is to use the function list(list("glm")) to compute the expected counts based on a model (design) matrix. The main functions are list(list("CFA")) and list(list("S2CFA")) (see details).
dataset_format: NA

(1978). list("Verteilungsfreie Methoden in der Biostatistik (Band II)") [Non-parametrical methods in the field of biometrics (Vol. II)]. Meisenheim am Glan, Germany: Hain. Lienert, G. A. (1971). dataset_title: Connectivity matrix for loco (Concholepas concholepas) from Chile
dataset_description: Sample connectivity matrix representing potential larval dispersal of loco (Concholepas concholepas) from Chile.  The matrix is for 89 sites along the coast of Chile and is derived from a theoretical larval transport model.
dataset_format: A square 89x89 matrix with real, positive elements.
dataset_reference: Garavelli L, Kaplan DM, Colas F, Stotz W, Yannicelli B, Lett C (2014) Identifying appropriate spatial scales for marine conservation and management using a larval dispersal model: The case of Concholepas concholepas (loco) in Chile. Progress in Oceanography 124:42-53. list(list("http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.pocean.2014.03.011"), list("doi:10.1016/j.pocean.2014.03.011"))

dataset_title: Sample LOD score data for simulated and real parent-child pairs
dataset_description: This dataset contains both simulated and real 'log of the odds ratio' (LOD) scores for potential parent-child pairs of humbug damselfish ( list("Dascyllus\n", "aruanus") ) from New Caledonia. Data was generated using list(list("http://www.pierroton.inra.fr/genetics/labo/Software/Famoz/index.html"), list("FaMoz")) . In all cases, results are for the potential parent with the highest LOD score for a given larval fish (child). Simulated data is based on artificial children generated from either real potential parent-pairs (the 'in' group) or artificial parents generated from observed allelic frequencies (the 'out' group).
dataset_format:
A list with 3 elements: list(list(list("in.group"), list("5000 maximum LOD 
", "  scores for simulated children from random crossing of real potential 
", "  parents")), list(list("out.group"), list("5000 maximum LOD scores for simulated children 
", "  from random crossing of artificial potential parents based on observed 
", "  allelic frequencies")), list(list("real.children"), list("Maximum LOD scores for 200 real
", "  juvenile fish")))
dataset_reference: Gerber S, Chabrier P, Kremer A (2003) FAMOZ: a software for parentage analysis using dominant, codominant and uniparentally inherited markers. Molecular Ecology Notes 3:479-481. list(list("http://dx.doi.org/10.1046/j.1471-8286.2003.00439.x"), list("doi:10.1046/j.1471-8286.2003.00439.x")) Kaplan et al. (submitted) Uncertainty in marine larval connectivity estimation

dataset_title: Partial Linear Least-squares Regression with Constrained Splines
dataset_description: Given a continuous response y and a continuous predictor x, and a design matrix Z of parametrically-modeled covariates, the model y=f(x)+Zb+e is fit using least-squares cone projection.   The function f is smooth and has one of eight user-defined shapes: increasing, decreasing, convex, concave, or combinations of monotonicity and convexity.   Quadratic splines are used for increasing and decreasing, while cubic splines are used for the other six shapes.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Meyer, M.C. (2008) Shape-Restricted Regression Splines, list("Annals of Applied Statistics") , list("2(3)") ,1013-1033.

dataset_title: Spatial interpolation (2D) by constrained, covariance-matching constrained and universal, global Point or Block Kriging
dataset_description: Function for constrained, covariance-matching constrained and universal (external drift kriging) point or block (of any shape) kriging in a global neighbourhood and for isotropic covariance models.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: See main help page of the list(list("constrainedKriging")) package.

dataset_title: Spatial Variance-Covariance Matrices for Points and Polygons of any Shape
dataset_description: The function list("preCKrige") provides (approximated) spatial variance-covariance matrices for user defined sets of polygons (blocks) of any shape or points for two-dimensional isotropic random fields.  The polygon (block) areas of a set of polygons (polygon neighbourhood configuration) are approximated by pixels and the block-block covariances are approximated by averaging the pixel covariances of the approximated polygon (block) areas. The returned object of is, in general, needed by list(list("CKrige")) for spatial point or block interpolation by constrained, covariance-matching constrained or universal (external drift) kriging.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: See main help page of the list(list("constrainedKriging")) package.

dataset_title: constrainedKriging a package for nonlinear spatial predictions with local change of support
dataset_description: The constrainedKriging package provides functions for tow-dimensional spatial interpolation by constrained, covariance-matching constrained and universal (external drift) kriging for points or block of any shape for data with a nonstationary mean function and an isotropic weakly stationary variogram.  The linear spatial interpolation methods, constrained and covariance-matching constrained kriging, provide approximately unbiased prediction for nonlinear target values under change of support. In principle, the package provides two user functions, preCKrige and CKrige to calculate spatial prediction in two steps: 1. Call of list(list("preCKrige")) to calculate the variance-covariance matrices for defined sets of points or polygons (blocks). 2. Call of list(list("CKrige")) by using the output of preCKrige to calculate the spatial interpolation by one of the three kriging methods.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: % Aldworth, J. and Cressie, N. (2003). Prediction of nonlinear spatial functionals. list("Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference") , list("112") , 3--41 Cressie, N. (1993). Aggregation in geostatistical problems. In A. Soares, editor, list("Geostatistics Troia 92") list("1") , pages 25--36, Dordrecht. Kluwer Academic Publishers. Hofer, C. and Papritz, A. (2010). Predicting threshold exceedance by local block means in soil pollution surveys. list("Mathematical Geosciences") . list("42") , 631-656, doi: 10.1007/s11004-010-9287-4 Hofer, C. and Papritz, A. (in preparation). constrainedKriging: an R-package for customary, constrained and covariance-matching constrained point or block kriging. list("Computers & Geosciences")

dataset_description: These data are the results of a chemical analysis of wines grown in the same region in Italy but derived from three different cultivars. The analysis determined the quantities of 13 constituents found in each of the three types of wine: Barolo, Grignolino, Barbera. The data set is used to evaluate the ability of the list("CNmixt()") function in clustering the data assuming unknown their cultivars.
dataset_format: This data frame contains 178 rows, each corresponding to a different cultivar of wine produced in Piedmont (Italy), and 14 columns. The first column is the type of wine ( list("Type") ), a factor variable with the following levels: list("Barolo") , list("Grignolino") list("Barbera") . The variables measured on the three types of wines are the following: list("Alcohol") list("Malic acid") list("Ash") list("Alcalinity") list("Magnesium") list("Phenols") list("Flavanoids") list("Nonflavanoids") list("Proanthocyanins") list("Color intensity") list("Hue") list("OD280.OD315Dilution") list("Proline") All variables but the label class are continuous.
dataset_source: This dataset is from the UCI machine learning repository and it is available at list("http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Wine") .

Chimica e Tecnologie Farmaceutiche ed Alimentari, Universita' di Genova.

dataset_title: cooccur: Probabilistic Species Co-occurrence Analysis in R
dataset_description: This R package applies the probabilistic model of species co-occurrence (Veech 2013) to a set of species distributed among a set of survey or sampling sites. The algorithm calculates the observed and expected frequencies of co-occurrence between each pair of species. The expected frequency is based on the distribution of each species being random and independent of the other species. The analysis returns the probabilities that a more extreme (either low or high) value of co-occurrence could have been obtained by chance. The package also includes functions for visualizing species co-occurrence results and preparing data for downstream analyses.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Veech (2013). A probabilistic model for analysing species co-occurrence. Global Ecology and Biogeography, DOI: 10.1111/j.1466-8238.2012.00789.x Griffith, Veech, and Marsh (2016). cooccur: Probabilistic Species Co-Occurrence Analysis in R. Journal of Statistical Software, 69(2), 1-17. doi:10.18637/jss.v069.c02

dataset_title: Basic Theoretical Copula, Empirical Copula, and Various Utility Functions
dataset_description:
The list("copBasic") package is oriented around copula theory and mathematical operations involving copulas and closely follows the standard texts by Nelsen (2006) and from 2015 list(list("+")) increasely Joe (2014) as well. Another recommended text is by Salvadori list("et al.") (2007) and is cited herein, but about half of that excellent book is on univariate applications. The primal objective of is to provide a basic application programming interface (API) to numerous results shown by authoritative texts on copulas. It is hoped in part that the package will help new inductees to copulas in their self study, potential course work, and applied circumstances. The language and vocabulary of copulas is quite formidable as this documentation exemplifies. The author (Asquith) has often emphasized list("vocabulary") words in list("italics") . Italic typeface is used extensively and usually near the opening of function-by-function documentation to identify vocabulary words, such as list("survival copula") (see list(list("surCOP")) ). This syntax tries to mimic and accentuate the word usage in Nelsen (2006) and Joe (2014). The package was started well before Joe (2014) so many more citations to Nelsen (2006) are made. The italics then are used to draw connections between concepts. In conjunction with the summary of functions in list("copBasic-package") , the extensive cross referencing to functions throughout and expansive indexing of this documentation should be beneficial. The author had no experience with copulas prior to a chance happening upon Nelsen (2006) in list("c.") 2008. The package is a personal list("tour de force") in self study. This package and user's manual hopefully is helpful to others. A few comments on notation are needed. A bold math typeface is used to represent a copula such as list(list("\mathbf{\Pi}")) list(list("P")) ) for the list("independence copula") . The syntax list(list("\mathcal{R}\times\mathcal{R} \equiv \mathcal{R}^2")) denotes the orthogonal domain of two real numbers, and list(list("[0,1]\times [0,1]")) list(list("\equiv")) list(list("\mathcal{I}\times\mathcal{I} \equiv \mathcal{I}^2")) denotes the orthogonal domain on the unit square of probabilities. Limits of integration list(list("[0,1]")) or list(list("[0,1]^2")) involving copulas are thus shown as list(list("\mathcal{I}")) and list(list("\mathcal{I}^2")) , respectively. The random variables list(list("X")) list(list("Y")) respectively denote the horizontal and vertical directions in list(list("\mathcal{R}^2")) . Their probabilistic counterparts are uniformly distributed random variables on , are respectively denoted as list(list("U")) list(list("V")) , and necessarily also are the respective directions in ( denotes the horizontal, denotes the vertical). Often realizations of these random variables are respectively list(list("x")) list(list("y")) for list(list("u")) list(list("v")) . There is an obvious difference between nonexceedance probability list(list("F")) and exceedance probability list(list("1-F")) . Both are measures in nonexceedance (cumulative probability). Arguments to many functions herein are list("u") list(list("= u")) list("v") list(list("= v")) and are almost list("exclusively nonexceedance") but there are instances for which the probability arguments are list(list("= 1 - u = u'")) list(list("= 1 - v = v'")) list() list("Helpful Navigation of the copBasic Package") Some helpful pivot points into the package are listed in the following table: list(list("lclr"), list("

")) Several of the functions listed above are measures of list("bivariate association.") Two of the measures ( list("Kendall's Tau") , list(list("tauCOP")) ; list("Spearman's Rho") list(list("rhoCOP")) ) are familiar. provides native support for their sample estimation of course, but each function can be used to call 's list("cor()") function for parallelism to the other measures. The other measures ( list("Blomqvist's Beta") list("Gini's Gamma") list("Hoeffding's Phi") list("Schweizer and Wolff's Sigma") list("Spearman's Footrule") ) support sample estimation by specially formed calls to their respective functions: list(list("blomCOP")) list(list("giniCOP")) list(list("hoefCOP")) list(list("wolfCOP")) , and list(list("footCOP")) . The documentation for Gini's Gamma ( ) shows extensive use of theoretical and sample compuations for all of these functions. list("Bivariate skewness") measures are supported in list(list("joeskewCOP")) list(list("nuskewCOP")) list(list("nustarCOP")) ) and list(list("uvlmoms")) list(list("uvskew")) ). Extensive discussion and example computations of bivariate skewness is provided in the documentation.  Lastly, so-called list("bivariate L-moments") list("bivariate L-comoments") of a copula are directly computable in list(list("bilmoms")) , and this function is the theoretical counterpart to the list("sample L-comoments") in the list("lmomco") package. Bivariate random simulation by several functions is identified in the previous table. The package explicitly uses only list("conditional simulation") also known as the list("conditional distribution method") for random variate generation following the guidance of Nelsen (2006, pp. 40--41) (see also list(list("simCOPmicro")) list(list("simCOP")) list(list("derCOPinv")) list(list("derCOPinv2")) ). There are many other methods in the literature and available in , and a comparison of some methods is made in the list("Examples") section of the Gumbel-Hougaard copula ( list(list("GHcop")) ). ")) The function list(list("jointCOP")) has considerable demonstration in its list("Note") section of the list("joint and") list("joint or") relations supported by simulation + counting scenarios. Also there is considerable demonstration in the section of function list(list("duCOP")) on application of the concepts of conditions, conditions, and importantly joint list("mutually exclusive or") conditions. One or two copulas can be list("composited,") list("combined,") list("multiplied") in interesting ways to create highly unique joint probability relations and complex dependence structures. provides the three functions for copula composition: list(list("composite1COP")) composites a single copula with two compositing parameters, list(list("composite2COP")) composites two copulas with two compositing parameters, and list(list("composite3COP")) composites two copulas with four compositing parameters. Two copulas can be combined through a weighted convex combination using list(list("convex2COP")) with a single weighting parameter. Copula multiplication of two copulas to form a third is supported by list(list("prod2COP")) . All of the five functions for compositing, combining, or multipling copulas are compatible with joint probability simulation ( ), measures of association ( list(list("\rho_\mathbf{C}")) ), and presumably all other copula operations using features. list(list("cclr"), list("

")) list("Useful Copula Relations by Visualization") There are a myriad of relations amongst variables computable through copulas, and these were listed in the earlier in this documentation. There is a script located in the list("inst/doc") directory of the sources titled list("CopulaRelations_BaseFigure_inR.txt") . This script demonstrates, using the list(list("PSP")) copula, relations between the copula ( list(list("COP")) ), survival copula ( ), joint survival function of a copula ( list(list("surfuncCOP")) ), co-copula ( list(list("coCOP")) ), and dual of a copula function ( ). The script performs simulation and manual counts observations meeting select criteria in order to compute their empirical probabilities. The script produces a list("base figure,") which after extending in a vector editing software application, is suitable for educational description, and is shown below. list(list("html"), list(list(list("CopulaRelationsFigure4pkg.jpg")))) list(list("latex"), list(list(list("CopulaRelationsFigure4pkg.pdf"), list("options: width=4.5in, trim=1in 2.25in 0.75in 1in, clip")))) list("A Review of ", list("Return Periods"), " using Copulas") Risk analyses of natural hazards are commonly expressed as list("annual return periods") list(list("T")) in years, which are defined for a nonexceedance probability list(list("q")) as list(list("T = 1/(1-q)")) . In bivariate analysis, there immediately emerge two types of return periods representing list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{coop}}")) list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{dual}}")) conditions between nonexceedances of the two hazard sources (random variables) . It is usual in many applications for to be expressed equivalently as a probability in common for both variables. Incidently, the list(list("\mathrm{Pr}[\,U > u \mid V > v\,]")) list(list("\mathrm{Pr}[\,V > v \mid U > u\,]")) probabilities also are useful for list("conditional return period") computations following Salvadori (2007, p. 159--160) but are not further considered here. Also the list(list("F_K(w)")) list("Kendall's Function") list("Kendall's Measure") of a copula) is the core tool for list("secondary return period") computations (see list(list("kfuncCOP")) Let the copula list(list("\mathbf{C}(u,v; \Theta)")) for nonexceedances be set for some copula family (formula) by a parameter vector list(list("\Theta")) . The copula family and parameters define the joint coupling (loosely meaning dependency/correlation) between hazards . If list("failure") occurs if list("either") list("both") hazards are a probability threshold ( list(list("u = v = 1 - 1/T = q")) ) for -year return period, then the list("real return period") of failure is defined using either the copula ( list(list("\mathbf{C}(q,q; \Theta)")) or the list("co-copula") list(list("\mathbf{C}^\star(q',q'; \Theta)")) ) for exceedance probability list(list("q' = 1 - q")) is list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{coop}} = \frac{1}{1 - \mathbf{C}(q, q; \Theta)} = \frac{1}{\mathbf{C}^\star(1-q, 1-q; \Theta)}\mbox{\ and}")) list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{coop}} \equiv \frac{1}{\mathrm{cooperative\ risk}}\mbox{.}")) Or in words, the hazard sources list("collaborate") list("cooperate") to cause failure. However, if failure only occurs if and only if occur simultaneously (that is the hazards must list("dually work together") ), then the real return period is defined using either the list("dual of a copula (function)") list(list("\tilde\mathbf{C}(q,q; \Theta)")) ), the list("joint survival function") list(list("\overline\mathbf{C}(q,q;\Theta)")) ), or list(list("\hat\mathbf{C}(q',q'; \Theta)")) ) as list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{dual}} = \frac{1}{1 - \tilde\mathbf{C}(q,q; \Theta)} = \frac{1}{\overline\mathbf{C}(q,q;\Theta)} = \frac{1}{\hat\mathbf{C}(q',q';\Theta)} \mbox{\ and}")) list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{dual}} \equiv \frac{1}{\mathrm{complement\ of\ dual\ protection}}\mbox{.}")) A numerical demonstration is informative. Salvadori (2007, p. 151) show for a list("Gumbel-Hougaard copula") ) having list(list("\Theta =")) 3.055 and list(list("T =")) 1,000 years ( list(list("q = 0.999")) ) that list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{coop}} = 797.1")) years and that = 1,341.4 years, which means that average return periods between failures are list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{coop}} \le T \le T_{q;\,\mathrm{dual}}\mbox{\ and thus}")) list(list("797.1 \le T \le 1314.4\mbox{\ years.}")) With the following code, these values are readily computed and verified using the list("prob2T()") function from the package along with functions (generic functional interface to a copula) and list("dual of a copula") ): list("
", "  q <- T2prob(1000)
", "  lmomco::prob2T(  COP(q,q, cop=GHcop, para=3.055)) #  797.110
", "  lmomco::prob2T(duCOP(q,q, cop=GHcop, para=3.055)) # 1341.438
") An early source (in 2005) by some of those authors cited on p. 151 of Salvadori (2007; their citation list("[67]") ) shows list(list("T_{q;\,\mathrm{dual}} = 798")) years---a rounding error seems to have been committed. Finally just for reference, a Gumbel-Hougaard copula having list(list("\Theta = 3.055")) corresponds to an analytical ) of list(list("\tau \approx 0.673")) , which can be verified through numerical integration available from as: list("
", "  tauCOP(cop=GHcop, para=3.055, brute = TRUE) # 0.6726542
") Thus, a list("better understanding of the statistical characteristics of [multiple hazard sources] requires the study of their joint distribution") (Salvadori , 2007, p. 150). list("Interaction of copBasic to Copulas in Other Packages") As mentioned in various places in this documentation, the is not intended to be a port of the numerous bivariate copulas and over re-implement other bivariate copulas available in . A demonstration showing an implemention of the Gaussian copula from the list("copula") package is shown in the section of list(list("med.regressCOP")) in a circumstance of ordinary least squares linear regression  compared to median regression of a copula as well as prediction limits of both regressions. Another demonstration in context of maximum pseudo-log-likelihood estimation of copula parameters is seen in the section list(list("mleCOP")) , and also see list(list("API to the copula package")) entry in the Index.

dataset_title: Mother Classes "Copula", etc of all Copulas in the Package
dataset_description: A copula is a multivariate distribution with uniform margins. The virtual class list("\"Copula\"") is the mother (or list("super\n", "    class") ) of all copula classes in the package list("copula") which encompasses classes of the former packages list("nacopula") and . list("\"parCopula\"") extends and is the super class of all copulas that can be fully list("par") ametrized and hence fitted to data.  For these, at least the list(list("dim"), "()") method must be well defined. list("\"copula\"") the mother of all copula classes from former package .  It has set of slots for the dimension and parameter vector, see below. list("\"xcopula\"") contains a slot ; an ( list("actual") ) class example are the rotated copulas, list(list("rotCopula"))

dataset_title: Simulated Data Based on Nominal Response IRT Model (Bock, 1972)
dataset_description: Data with 40 items is simulated based on the Nominal Response IRT Model (Bock, 1972). Each variable (column) represents an item and is a "character" variable. This is necessary to be able to run the list(list("CopyDetect2")) function. The items are assumed to have five response alternatives: A, B, C, D, and E. The item parameters used to generate data are taken from Wollack's study (1996).
dataset_format: A data frame with 500 hypothetical simulees.
dataset_reference: Wollack, J.A.(1996). Detection of answer copying using item response theory. list("Dissertation Abstracts International, 57/05") , 2015. list() Bock (1972). Estimating item parameters and latent ability when responses are scored in two or more nominal categories. list("Psychometrika, 37") , 29-51 .

", 
    "    ", list(list(list("Intercept.A")), list("NRM intercept parameter for response alternative A")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Intercept.B")), list("NRM intercept parameter for response alternative B")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Intercept.C")), list("NRM intercept parameter for response alternative C")), "

dataset_title: Sample data for Correlational Class Analysis.
dataset_description: A randomly generated sample dataset for correlational class analysis, created using the approach described in Boutyline (under review). rownames(cca.example) contain the true schematic class membership for each row.  Every row belonging to one schematic class was created from noisy linear transformations of the same vector.
dataset_source: Boutyline, Andrei. Under review. "Correlational Class Analysis Draws a More Accurate Map (Comment on Goldberg)." Working paper available from list("www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~andrei") .

dataset_description:
This package implements the Correlational Class Analysis methodology described by Boutyline (under review). The correlational class analysis of a survey dataset produces a partition of the population into separate modules.  This is done in four steps: list("
", "    ", list(), " Create a matrix G of absolute row correlations. This is the network adjacency matrix.
", "    ", list(), " Set statistically insignificant correlations to 0 to reduce noise. 
", "    ", list(), " Use igraph's leading.eigenvector.community to partition this network into modules.
", "    ", list(), " Return an object describing the resulting class assignments (as well as the separate data frames describing the individual modules.)
") CCA substantially improves the accuracy of the Relational Class Analysis (RCA) algorithm proposed by Goldberg (2011). See Boutyline (under review) for details.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Boutyline, Andrei. Under review. "Correlational Class Analysis Draws a More Accurate Map (Comment on Goldberg)." Working paper available from list("www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~andrei") .

dataset_description: Example files for running various functions in list("corHMM") . The list("primates") dataset comes from the example files provided by BayesTraits, though here we only include a single tree with branch lengths scaled to time. The list("primates.paint") dataset is the same, but with the tree painted according to hypothetical regimes. Finally, the list("rayDISC.example") dataset provides an example on how polymorphic data can be coded for list("rayDISC") .
dataset_format: a list object that contains a tree of class list("phylo") and a dataframe that contains the trait data
dataset_reference: Pagel, M., and A. Meade. 2006. Bayesian analysis of correlated evolution of discrete characters by reversible-jump Markov chain Monte Carlo. American Naturalist 167:808-825.

dataset_description: This data set contains a subset of yeast cell cycle data taken from Spellman et al. (1998) (See the reference below). Spellman et al. (1998) monitored the genome-wide mRNA levels for 6108 yeast genes at 7-minute intervals for 119 minutes. A total of 256 genes were identified to oscillate significantly in at least two data sets. This example data set contains the log ratios of these 256 genes at the first 16 time points(from 0 min to 105 min).
dataset_format:
A list comprised of three components: list("normalizedData") , list("normalizedData.sample") and list("designMatrix") . list("
", "  ", list(), " ", list("normalizedData"), " is a three dimensional array containing the normalized expression data of the 256 genes during yeast cell-cycle. 
", "  ", list(), " ", list("normalizedData.sample"), " is a randomly selected sample from ", list("normalizedData"), ". It only contains 64 genes.
", "  ", list(), " ", list("designMatrix"), " is a three dimensional array used to fit the clustering of linear mixed models (CLMM).
", " ")
dataset_reference: Spellman et al. (1998). Comprehensive identification of cell cycle-regulated genes of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae by microarray hybridization. list("Molecular Biology of the Cell") ,9, 3273-3297

dataset_title: Yeast Cell Cycle Data Sets of wild type and single mutant
dataset_description: This data set is taken from a yeast cell cycle study in Qin et al. (2014) (See the reference below). It contains the normalized data of 256 cell cycle dependent genes in wild type(WT) and single mutant(SM) yeast, each mesured over time with two technical replicates.
dataset_format:
A list comprised of four components: list("normalizedData.WT") , list("normalizedData.SM") list("designMatrix.WT") , and list("designMatrix.SM") . list("
", "  ", list(), " ", list("normalizedData.WT"), " and ", list("normalizedData.SM"), " are three-dimensional 
", "  arrays containing the normalized expression data for 256 genes in WT and SM yeast, respectively. Missing values are indicated by "NA". 
", "  ", list(), " ", list("designMatrix.WT"), " and ", list("designMatrix.SM"), " are three-dimensional arrays
", "   used to fit the clustering of linear mixed models (CLMM).
", " ")
dataset_reference: Li-Xuan Qin, Linda Breeden and Steven G. Self (2014). Finding gene clusters for a replicated time course study. list("BMC Res Notes") 7:60.

dataset_description: Zhao et al. (2004) studied gene expression profiles of two types of breast cancer, invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC). They analyzed the expression profiles of 38 IDC samples and 21 ILC samples, using cDNA arrays spotted for 42,000 clones. With the significance analysis of microarrays (SAM) method (Efron et al., 2001), they identified a total of 474 clones that were differentially expressed between IDCs and ILCs, representing 354 unique genes. This example data set contains the normalized expression value of these 354 genes for the 59 samples.
dataset_format:
list("
", "  ", list(), " A list comprised of two components: ", list("normalizedData"), " and ", list("designMatrix"), ".
", "  ", list(), " ", list("normalizedData"), " is a matrix containing the normalized breast cancer data, whose row 
", "  names are gene IDs and column names indicate two subtypes of breast cancer (IDC vs. ILC).
", "  ", list(), " ", list("designMatrix"), " is the covariates matrix used to fit the clustering of
", "  linear models (CLM), whose row names are samples and column names are covariates.
", 
    " ")
dataset_reference: Zhao et al. (2004).  Different gene expression patterns in invasive lobular and ductal carcinomas of the breast. list("Molecular Biology \n", "  of the Cell") ,15, 2523-2536

dataset_description: Lu et al. (2005) profiled both miRNA expression and mRNA expression in multiple human cancer types. The miRNA profiles reflected the developmental lineage and differentiation state of the tumours. One of the profiled miRNA is let-7f. Its expression is highly correlated (Pearson correlation < -0.458) with the expression of 178 genes in tumors from 5 cancer types.
dataset_format:
A list comprised of two components: list("normalizedData") and list("designMatrix") . list("
", "  ", list(), " ", list("normalizedData"), " is a matrix containing the normalized data of the miR-let-7f targets, whose row 
", "  names are gene IDs and column names indicate normal and tumor samples of 5 types of cancer.
", "  ", list(), " ", list("designMatrix"), " is the covariates matrix used to fit the clustering of
", "  linear models (CLM), whose row names are samples and column names are covariates.
", " ")
dataset_reference: Lu et al. (2005). MicroRNA expression profiles classify human cancers. list("Nature") , 435, 834-838

dataset_title: corpora: statistical inference from corpus frequency data
dataset_description: The list("corpora") provides some convenience functions and example data sets for statistical inference from corpus frequency data. It is a companion package for the SIGIL course ( list("Statistical Inference - a Gentle Introduction for Linguists and similar creatures") ) developed by Marco Baroni and Stefan Evert.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: The official homepage of both the SIGIL course and the corpora package is list("http://SIGIL.R-Forge.R-Project.org/") .

dataset_title: Comparison of written and spoken frequencies (BNC)
dataset_description: This data set compares the frequencies of 60 selected nouns in the written and spoken parts of the British National Corpus, World Edition (BNC).  Nouns were chosen from three frequency bands, namely the 20 most frequent nouns in the corpus, 20 nouns with approximately 1000 occurrences, and 20 nouns with approximately 100 occurrences. See Aston & Burnard (1998) for more information about the BNC, or go to list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") .
dataset_format:
A data set with 61 rows and the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("noun"), ":"), list("lemmatised noun (aka stem form)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("written"), ":"), list("frequency in the written part of the BNC")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("spoken"), ":"), list("frequency in the spoken part of the BNC")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Aston, Guy and Burnard, Lou (1998). list("The BNC Handbook.") Edinburgh University Press, Edinburgh. See also the BNC homepage at list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") .

dataset_description: This data set gives the number of documents and tokens in each of the 18 domains represented in the British National Corpus, World Edition (BNC).  See Aston & Burnard (1998) for more information about the BNC and the domain classification, or go to list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") .
dataset_format:
A data set with 19 rows and the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("domain"), ":"), list("name of the respective domain in the BNC")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("documents"), ":"), list("number of documents from this domain")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("tokens"), ":"), list("total number of tokens in all documents from
", "      this domain")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Aston, Guy and Burnard, Lou (1998). list("The BNC Handbook.") Edinburgh University Press, Edinburgh. See also the BNC homepage at list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") .

dataset_title: Collocations of the phrase "in charge of" (BNC)
dataset_description: This data set lists collocations (in the sense of Sinclair 1991) of the phrase list("in charge of") found in the British National Corpus, World Edition (BNC).  A span size of 3 and a frequency threshold of 5 were used, i.e. all words that occur at least five times within a distance of three tokens from the key phrase are listed as collocates.  Note that collocations were not allowed to cross sentence boundaries. See Aston & Burnard (1998) for more information about the BNC, or go to list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") .
dataset_format:
A data set with 250 rows and the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("collocate"), ":"), list("a collocate of the key phrase ", list("in charge of"), " (word form)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("f.in"), ":"), list("occurrences of the collocate within a distance of
", "      3 tokens from the key phrase, i.e. ", list("inside"), " the span")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("N.in"), ":"), list("total number of tokens inside the span")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("f.out"), ":"), list("occurrences of the collocate ", list("outside"), 
    " the span")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("N.out"), ":"), list("total number of tokens outside the span")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Aston, Guy and Burnard, Lou (1998). list("The BNC Handbook.") Edinburgh University Press, Edinburgh. See also the BNC homepage at list("http://www.natcorp.ox.ac.uk/") . Sinclair, John (1991). list("Corpus, Concordance, Collocation.") Oxford University Press, Oxford.

The Perl scripts used in the extraction procedure are available from list("http://cwb.sourceforge.net/download.php#import")

dataset_title: A small corpus of very short stories with linguistic annotations
dataset_description: This data set contains a small corpus (8043 tokens) of short stories from the collection list("Very Short Stories") (VSS, see list("http://www.schtepf.de/pages/stories.html") ).  The text was automatically segmented (tokenised) and annotated with part-of-speech tags (from the Penn tagset) and lemmas (base forms), using the IMS TreeTagger (Schmid 1994).
dataset_format:
A data set with 8043 rows corresponding to tokens and the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("word"), ":"), list("the word form (or surface form) of the token")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("pos"), ":"), list("the part-of-speech tag of the token (using the Penn tagset)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("word"), ":"), list("the lemma (or base form) of the token")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Schmid, Helmut (1994). Probabilistic part-of-speech tagging using decision trees. In: list("Proceedings of the International Conference\n", "  on New Methods in Language Processing (NeMLaP)") , pages 44-49.

dataset_title: Biber's (1988) register features for the British National Corpus
dataset_description: This data set contains a table of the relative frequencies (per 1000 words) of 65 linguistic features (Biber 1988, 1995) for each text document in the British National Corpus (Aston & Burnard 1998). Biber (1988) introduced these features for the purpose of a multidimensional register analysis. Variables in the data set are numbered according to Biber's list (see e.g. Biber 1995, 95f). Feature frequencies were automatically extracted from the British National Corpus using query patterns based on part-of-speech tags (Gasthaus 2007).  Note that features 60 and 65 had to be omitted because they cannot be identified with sufficient accuracy by the automatic methods.  For further information on the extraction methodology, see Gasthaus (2007, 20-21).  The original data set and the Python scripts used for feature extraction are available from list("http://cogsci.uni-osnabrueck.de/~CL/research/gasthaus2007/") .

dataset_title: FT-Raman spectra of furan maleimide based self-healing polymer
dataset_description: Six preprocessed FT-Raman spectra of a self-healing polymer. The wavenumber region shows the C=C vibrations of furan, maleimide and their respective Diels-Alder adduct. The row names show the measurement temperature in degree Celsius, while the column names show the relative wavenumber.
dataset_format: A matrix containing 6 spectra by rows with 145 wavenumbers by columns.
dataset_source: R. Geitner, J. Koetteritzsch, M. Siegmann, T. Bocklitz, M. Hager, U. S. Schubert, S. Graefe, B. Dietzek, M. Schmitt and J. Popp (2015) <DOI:10.1039/C5CP02151K>

dataset_description: This is a classical developmental toxicology data set. Pregnant banded Dutch rabbits were treated with one of four levels of a chemical. The actual doses are not known, instead the groups are designated as Control, Low, Medium, and High. Before term the animals were sacrificed, and the total number of fetuses, as well as the number affected by the treatment was recorded.
dataset_format:
A 'CBData' object, that is a data frame  with the following variables list(list("ll"), list("
", "    Trt          ", list(), " factor giving treatment group", list(), "
", "    ClusterSize  ", list(), " the size of the litter", list(), "
", "    NResp        ", list(), " the number of affected fetuses", list(), "
", "    Freq         ", list(), " the number of litters with the given ClusterSize/NResp combination", list(), "
", "  "))
dataset_source: Paul, S. R. (1982) Analysis of proportions of affected foetuses in teratological experiments. list("Biometrics") , 38, 361-370. This data set has been analyzed (and listed) in numerous papers, including Rao, J. N. K. & Scott, A. J. (1992) A Simple Method for the Analysis of Clustered Data. , 48, 577-586. George, E. O. & Kodell, R. L. (1996) Tests of Independence, Treatment Heterogeneity, and Dose-Related Trend With Exchangeable Binary Data. list("Journal of the American Statistical Association") , 91, 1602-1610. Lee, S. (2003) Analysis of the Binary Littermate Data in the One-Way Layout. list("Biometrical Journal") , 45, 195-206.

dataset_description: The data set is based on a developmental toxicity experiment on the effect of ethylene glycol diethyl ether (EGDE) on fetal development of New Zealand white rabbits. In the study, four groups of pregnant does were randomly assigned to dose levels $0, 25, 50$, and $100$ milligrams per kilogram body weight of EGDE. For each litter and at each dose level, the adverse response used is the combined number of fetal malformation and fetal death.
dataset_format:
A 'CBData' object, that is a data frame  with the following variables list(list("ll"), list("
", "    Trt          ", list(), " factor giving treatment group", list(), "
", "    ClusterSize  ", list(), " the size of the litter", list(), "
", "    NResp        ", list(), " the number of affected fetuses", list(), "
", "    Freq         ", list(), " the number of litters with the given ClusterSize/NResp combination", list(), "
", "  "))
dataset_source: Krewski, D., Zhu, Y. \& Fung, K. (1995). Statistical analysis of overdispersed multinomial data from developmental toxicity studies. In list("Statistics in Toxicology") , Ed. B. Morgan, pp.\ 151--179.  New York: Oxford University Press.

dataset_title: Developmental toxicology study of DEHP in mice
dataset_description: This data set is based on a National Toxicology Program study on diethylhexyl phthalate, DEHP. Pregnant CD-1 mice were randomly assigned to receive 0, 250, 500, 1000, or 1500 ppm of DEHP in their feed during gestational days 0-17. The uterine contents of the mice were examined for toxicity endpoints prior to normal delivery. The possible outcomes are 1) malformation, 2) death or resorption, 3) no adverse event.
dataset_format:
A 'CMData' object, that is a data frame  with the following variables list(list("ll"), list("
", "    Trt          ", list(), " factor giving treatment group", list(), "
", "    ClusterSize  ", list(), " the size of the litter", list(), "
", "    NResp.1        ", list(), " the number of fetuses with a type 1 outcome (malformation) ", list(), "
", "    NResp.2        ", list(), " the number of fetuses with a type 2 outcome (death or resorption) ", list(), "
", "    NResp.3        ", list(), " the number of fetuses with a type 3 outcome (normal) ", list(), "
", 
    "    Freq         ", list(), " the number of litters with the given ClusterSize/NResp.1-NResp.3 combination", list(), "
", "  "))
dataset_source: National Toxicology Program, NTP Study TER84064.
dataset_reference: Tyl, R. W., Price, C. J., Marr, M. C., and Kimmel, C. A. (1988). Developmental toxicity evaluation of dietary di(2-ethylhexy)phthalate in Fischer 344 rats and CD-1 mice. list("Fundamental and Applied Toxicology") 10, 395-412.

dataset_title: Nonparameterics for Correlated Binary and Multinomial Data
dataset_description: This package implements nonparametric methods for analysing exchangeable binary and multinomial data with variable cluster sizes with emphasis on trend testing. The input should specify the treatment group, cluster-size, and the number of responses (i.e. the number of cluster elements with the outcome of interest) for each cluster.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Szabo A, George EO. (2009) On the Use of Stochastic Ordering to Test for Trend with Clustered Binary Data. list("Biometrika") Stefanescu, C. & Turnbull, B. W. (2003) Likelihood inference for exchangeable binary data with varying cluster sizes. list("Biometrics") , 59, 18-24 Pang, Z. & Kuk, A. (2007) Test of marginal compatibility and smoothing methods for exchangeable binary data with unequal cluster sizes. , 63, 218-227

dataset_title: A test dataset of class list("xcmsRaw") .
dataset_description: A few seconds extracted from a GC-APCI-MS run using a Bruker impact II.
dataset_format: The format is based on class 'xcmsRaw' [package "xcms"] with several slots. The slots which will be used by the functions are 'env', 'scantime' and 'scanindex'. Only individual intensity values within 'env$intensity' will be modified.

dataset_title: A test dataset of class list("mzXML") .
dataset_description: A test dataset imported by read.mzXML() from a GC-APCI measurement on a Bruker impact II, exported by Compass to an mzXML file.
dataset_format: The full format depends on the source mzXML (different vendors export different fields). However, raw data should be stored within list element 'scan' containing sublist elements for 'mass' and 'peaks'. The class-attribute needs to be 'mzXML' such that list("CorrectOverloadedPeaks") can recognize it.

dataset_description: Danish data from 1953-1977 giving the correlations between nesting storks, human birth rate and per capita electricity consumption.
dataset_format: A matrix of correlations
dataset_reference: Gabriel, K. R. and Odoroff, C. L. (1990) Biplots in biomedical research. list("Statistics in Medicine") 9(5): pp. 469-485.

dataset_description: Matrix of marks for five exams, two with closed books and three with open books (Mechanics (C), Vectors (C), Algebra (O), Analysis (O) and Statistics (O)).
dataset_format: A data matrix
dataset_reference: Mardia, K.V., Kent, J.T. and Bibby, J.M. (1979) list("Multivariate\n", "   Analysis") , Academic Press London.

dataset_description: Heights of 1375 mothers and daughters (in cm) in the UK in 1893-1898.

dataset_reference: Weisberg, S. (2005) list("Applied Linear Regression") , John Wiley \& Sons, New Jersey

dataset_format: A matrix of correlations

dataset_title: Correlation matrix of characteristics of Australian athletes
dataset_description: Correlation matrix of 12 characteristics of Austration athletes (Sex, Height, Weight, Lean Body Mass, RCC, WCC, Hc, Hg, Ferr, BMI, SSF, Bfat)
dataset_format: A matrix of correlations

dataset_description: Correlations of 13 fysiological variables (sys, dia, p.p., pul, cort, u.v., tot/100, adr/100, nor/100, adr/tot, tot/hr, adr/hr, nor/hr) obtained from 48 medical students
dataset_format: A matrix of correlations
dataset_reference: Hills, M (1969) On looking at large correlation matices list("Biometrika") 56(2): pp. 249.

dataset_description: list("Example.Data") is a hypothetical dataset constructed to demonstrate some of the functions in the package. Data are provided for a hypothetical experiment in which a stimulus is provided under different experimental conditions. The outcome is a normally distributed variable. The entire experiment is repeated multiple times (cycle) in each patient.
dataset_format:
A list("data.frame") with list(list("360")) observations on list(list("5")) variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("Id")), list("The Subject identifier.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Cycle")), list("The same experiment is repeated multiple times in a patient. Cycle indicates the order of these repeated experiments.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Condition")), list("The experimental condition under which the outcome was measured.")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Time")), list("The time point at which the outcome was measured.")), "

    list("A continuous outcome.")), "

dataset_title: The protein protein interaction network data
dataset_description: A two column matrix containing with each row containing the names of the interacting gene pairs

dataset_title: The scaled ECF statistics of all the edges
dataset_description: The scaled ECF statistics measuring the differential correlation of all the edges

dataset_title: The scaled ECF-statistics of all the edges
dataset_description: The scaled ECF-statistics measuring the differential correlation of all the edges

dataset_title: The simulated data sets used in the paper
dataset_description: It contains case data set1 to set6, as well as a common control dataset

dataset_title: The unstandardized F-statistics and ECF-statistics of simulated dataset 1
dataset_description: Generated by the function of "diff_gen" which performs comparative analysis of differential gene expression patterns between the simulated case dataset1 and control dataset

dataset_title: The standardized F-statistics and ECF-statistics for the comparison between simulated data1 and the control data
dataset_description: This data is a list containing two components, the first component is a vector of length 500 which contains the F-statistics measuring differential expression of single genes, and the second component is a 500 by 500 matrix containing the ECF-statistics measuring the differential correlation of gene pairs

dataset_title: Result of genetic algorithm search for simulated data set1
dataset_description: This data set contains the result of the subnetwork extraction using genetic algorithm applied to the analysis of the differential expression pattern between simulated dataset1 and the control dataset

Simulated data set to illustrate the cosinor model. list("Y") is an outcome variable that varies of time list("time") according to a cosine curve. The binary covariate list("X") is associated with the mean and amplitude of the cosine curve.
dataset_format: A data frame with 3 variables: list("X") , list("Y") list("time") .

dataset_title: Photometric redshift estimation based on generalized linear models
dataset_description: This package provides an user-friendly interfaces to perform fast and reliable photometric redshift estimation. The code makes use of generalized linear models and can adopt gamma or inverse gaussian families, either from a frequentist or a Bayesian perspective. The code additionally provides a Shiny application providing a simple user interface.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: The US national Medicare inpatient hospital database is referred to as the Medpar data, which is prepared yearly from hospital filing records. Medpar files for each state are also prepared. The full Medpar data consists of 115 variables. The national Medpar has some 14 million records, with one record for each hospilitiztion. The data in the medpar file comes from 1991 Medicare files for the state of Arizona. The data are limited to only one diagnostic group (DRG 112). Patient data have been randomly selected from the original data.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 1495 observations on the following 10 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("los")), list("length of hospital stay")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("hmo")), list("Patient belongs to a Health Maintenance Organization, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("white")), list("Patient identifies themselves as Caucasian, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("died")), list("Patient died, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("age80")), list("Patient age 80 and over, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("type")), list("Type of admission, categorical")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("type1")), list("Elective admission, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("type2")), list("Urgent admission,binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("type3")), list("Elective admission, binary")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("provnum")), list("Provider ID")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: 1991 National Medpar data, National Health Economics & Research Co.
dataset_reference: Hilbe, Joseph M (2014), Modeling Count Data, Cambridge University Press Hilbe, Joseph M (2007, 2011), Negative Binomial Regression, Cambridge University Press Hilbe, Joseph M (2009), Logistic Regression Models, Chapman & Hall/CRC first used in Hardin, JW and JM Hilbe (2001, 2007), Generalized Linear Models and Extensions, Stata Press

dataset_description: grouped format of the lbw data. The observation level data come to us form Hosmer and Lemeshow (2000). Birthweights under 2500g classifies a low birthweight baby.

dataset_description: Data from Fair (1978). Although Fair used a tobit model with the data, the outcome measure can be modeled as a count. In fact, Greene (2003) modeled it as Poisson, but given the amount of overdispersion in the data, employing a negative binomial model is an appropriate strategy. The data is stored in the affairs data set. Naffairs is the response variable, indicating the number of affairs reported by the participant in the past year.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 601 observations on the following 18 variables. list("
", "   ", list(list(list("naffairs")), list("number of affairs within last year")), "

    list("(1/0) very happily married")), "

    "yrsmarr2")), list("(1/0) >1.5 yrs")), "

dataset_description: Data come from the 1991 Arizona cardiovascular patient files. A subset of the fields was selected to model the differential length of stay for patients entering the hospital to receive one of two standard cardiovascular procedures: CABG and PTCA. CABG is the standard acronym for Coronary Artery Bypass Graft, where the flow of blood in a diseased or blocked coronary artery or vein has been grafted to bypass the diseased sections. PTCA, or Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty, is a method of placing a balloon in a blocked coronary artery to open it to blood flow. It is a much less severe method of treatment for those having coronary blockage, with a corresponding reduction in risk.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 3589 observations on the following 6 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("los")), list("length of hospital stay")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("procedure")), list("1=CABG;0=PTCA")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("sex")), list("1=Male; 0=female")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("admit")), list("1=Urgent/Emerg; 0=elective (type of admission)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("age75")), list("1= Age>75; 0=Age<=75")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("hospital")), list("encrypted facility code (string)")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: 1991 Arizona Medpar data, cardiovascular patient files, National Health Economics & Research Co.
dataset_reference: Hilbe, Joseph M (2014), Modeling Count Data, Cambridge University Press Hilbe, Joseph M (2007, 2011), Negative Binomial Regression, Cambridge University Press Hilbe, Joseph M (2009), Logistic Regression Models, Chapman & Hall/CRC

dataset_description: The fishing data is adapted from Zuur, Hilbe and Ieno (2013) to determine whether the data appears to be generated from more than one generating mechanism. The data are originally adapted from Bailey et al. (2008) who were interested in how certain deep-sea fish populations were impacted when commercial fishing began in locations with deeper water than in previous years. Given that there are 147 sites that were researched, the model is of (1) the total number of fish counted per site (totabund); ( 2)  on the mean water depth per site (meandepth); (3) adjusted by the area of the site (sweptarea); (4) the log of which is the model offset.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 147 observations on the following variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("totabund")), list("total fish counted per site")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("meandepth")), list("mean water depth per site")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("sweptarea")), list("adjusted area of site")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("density")), list("folage density index")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("site")), list("catch site")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("year")), list("1977-2002")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("period")), list("0=1977-1989; 1=2000+")), 
    "
", "    ")
dataset_source: Zuur, Hilbe, Ieno (2013), A Beginner's Guide to GLM and GLMM using R,
dataset_reference: Hilbe, Joseph M (2014), Modeling Count Data, Cambridge University Press Zuur, Hilbe, Ieno (2013), A Beginner's Guide to GLM and GLMM using R, Highlands. Bailey M. et al (2008), "Longterm changes in deep-water fish populations in the North East Atlantic", Proc Roy Soc B 275:1965-1969.

dataset_description: Squirrel data set (nuts) from Zuur, Hilbe, and Ieno (2013).  As originally reported by Flaherty et al (2012), researchers recorded information about squirrel behavior and forest attributes across various plots in Scotland's Abernathy Forest. The study focused on the following variables. response      cones	 number of cones stripped by red squirrels per plot predictor  	sntrees  standardized number of trees per plot sheight standardized mean tree height per plot scover   standardized percentage of canopy cover per plot The stripped cone count was only taken when the mean diameter of trees was under 0.6m (dbh).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 52 observations on the following 8 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("cones")), list("number cones stripped by squirrels")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("ntrees")), list("number of trees per plot")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("dbh")), list("number DBH per plot")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("height")), list("mean tree height per plot")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("cover")), list("canopy closure (as a percentage)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("sntrees")), list("standardized number of trees per plot")), "
", "    ", list(
    list(list("sheight")), list("standardized mean tree height per plot")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("scover")), list("standardized canopy closure (as a percentage)")), "
", "    ")
dataset_source: Zuur, Hilbe, Ieno (2013), A Beginner's Guide to GLM and GLMM using R, Highlands
dataset_reference: Hilbe, Joseph M (2014), Modeling Count Data, Cambridge University Press Zuur, Hilbe, Ieno (2013), A Beginner's Guide to GLM and GLMM using R, Highlands. Flaherty, S et al (2012), "The impact of forest stand structure on red squirrels habitat use", Forestry 85:437-444.

dataset_description: Data from a subset of the German Socio-Economic Panel  (SOEP). The subset was created by Rabe-Hesketh and Skrondal (2005). Only working women are included in these data. Beginning in 1997, German health reform in part entailed a 200 % increase in patient co-payment as well as limits in provider reimbursement. Patients were surveyed for the one year panel (1996) prior to and the one year panel (1998) after reform to assess whether the number of physician visits by patients declined - which was the goal of reform legislation. The response, or variable to be explained by the model, is numvisit, which indicates the number of patient visits to a physician's office during a three month period.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 2,227 observations on the following 13 variables. list("
", "   ", list(list(list("numvisit")), list("visits to MD office 3mo prior")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("reform")), list("1=interview yr post-reform: 1998;0=pre-reform:1996")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("badh")), list("1=bad health; 0 = not bad health")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("age")), list("Age(yrs 20-60)")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("educ")), list("education(1:7-10;2=10.5-12;3=HSgrad+)")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("educ1")), list("educ1= 7-10 years")), "
", "   ", list(
    list(list("educ2")), list("educ2= 10.5-12 years")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("educ3")), list("educ3= post secondary or high school")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("agegrp")), list("age: 1=20-39; 2=40-49; 3=50-60")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("age1")), list("age 20-39")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("age2")), list("age 40-49")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("age3")), list("age 50-60")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("loginc")), list("log(household income in DM)")), "
", "  ")

dataset_title: Number of trials (implantations) of data of Williams (1996).

dataset_description: The data are the numbers of attempts at foraging by 20 adult and 20 immature green-backed herons. The data are listed as grouped (adult or immature) count data i.e. number of herons having a particular count value.
