dataset_description: A dataframe containing the Olson/IANA time zone designation of each US county, based on the county's Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) code. This dataset was put together based on county FIPS codes as of the 2010 US Census, using text from the two websites listed in "Sources" to set the time zone designation for each county.
dataset_format:
A dataframe with 3,143 rows and 4 variables: list("
", "  ", list(list("fips"), list("A numeric vector giving the county's four- or five-digit
", "              Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) code")), "
", "  ", list(list("tz"), list("A character vector with the county's Olson/IANA time zone
", "            designation")), "
", "  ", list(list("county"), list("A character vector giving the county's name")), "
", "  ", list(list("state"), list("A character vector giving the county's state")), "
")

dataset_description: A dataframe containing county-specific data: state, FIPS code, name, latitude and longitude of geographic center, and region code. It includes each U.S. county as of the 2010 census. This dataset was put together using a dataframe from the U.S. Census Bureau, which was pulled from the website listed in "Source." (Note: The names---in county, state format---for each county were pulled from the 2010 U.S. Census file found here: list("http://www2.census.gov/geo/docs/reference/cenpop2010/county/CenPop2010_Mean_CO.txt") .)
dataset_format:
A dataframe with 3,143 rows and 5 variables: list("
", "   ", list(list("state"), list("A character vector giving the two-letter abbreviation for
", "                the state of each county")), "
", "   ", list(list("fips"), list("A numeric vector giving the county's five-digit Federal
", "               Information Processing Standard (FIPS) code")), "
", "   ", list(list("name"), list("A character vector giving the name and state for each county")), "
", "   ", list(list("latitude"), list("A numeric vector giving the latitude of the geographic
", 
    "                   center of each county")), "
", "   ", list(list("longitude"), list("A numeric vector giving the longitude of the geographic
", "                    center of each county")), "
", "   ", list(list("region"), list("A numeric vector giving the four-digit or five-digit Federal
", "                 Information Processing Standard (FIPS) code (values in this
", "                 column are identical to those in the "fips" column, but do
", "                 not include leading zeros)")), 
    "
")

dataset_description: A dataframe containing the FIPS code and estimated radius (in km) for each U.S. county. This dataset was put together using a dataset from the U.S. Census American FactFinder data dissemination tool. This dataset was downloaded from the geographic identifiers 'G001' option for the 2010 Summary File1 (SF1). The file was found by following the instructions recommended by the U.S. census here: list("https://ask.census.gov/faq.php?id=5000&faqId=7825") . The website listed in "Source" gives more information about this dataset.
dataset_format:
A dataframe with 3,143 rows and 2 variables: list("
", "
", "   ", list(list("fips"), list("A character vector giving the county's five-digit Federal
", "               Information Processing Standard (FIPS) code")), "
", "
", "   ", list(list("county_radius"), list("A numeric vector giving an estimate for each
", "                        county's radius from its center, in km. This value
", "                        was calculated by dividing the U.S. Census Land Area
", "                        estimates (which are in square meters) by 1,000,000,
", 
    "                        and then taking the square root of each area and
", "                        dividing by pi. Each county was estimated to be
", "                        roughly circular for the purposes of estimating
", "                        county radii.")), "
")

dataset_title: A simultaneous regression model for the mean and covariance
dataset_description: This package fits a simultaneous regression model for the mean vectors and covariance matrices of multivariate response variables, as described in Hoff and Niu (2012). The explanatory variables can be continuous or discrete. The current version of the package provides the Bayesian estimates.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: P.D. Hoff and X. Niu. A Covariance Regression Model. Statistica Sinica, 22:729-753, 2012

dataset_description: This data is simulated. The covariates, X, are all generated from a standard normal distribution and they are all independent except for list(list("x_7"), list("x7")) and list(list("x_8"), list("x8")) (cor( , )=0.5). The code generating the data is list() list("library(MASS)") list("set.seed(9327529)") list("n<-1000") list("eta<-mvrnorm(n,rep(0,2),diag(1,2,2))") list("Sigma=diag(1,10,10)") list("Sigma[7,8]<-Sigma[8,7]<-0.5") list("X<-mvrnorm(n,rep(0,10),Sigma)") list("y0<-2+2*X[,1]+2*X[,2]+2*X[,5]+2*X[,6]+2*X[,8]+eta[,1]") list("y1<-4+2*X[,1]+2*X[,2]+2*X[,5]+2*X[,6]+2*X[,8]+eta[,2]") list("e<-1/(1+exp(-0.5*X[,1]-0.5*X[,2]-0.5*X[,3]-0.5*X[,4]-0.5*X[,7]))") list("T<-rbinom(n,1,e)") list("y<-y1*T+y0*(1-T)") list("datc<-data.frame(x1=X[,1],x2=X[,2],x3=X[,3],x4=X[,4],x5=X[,5],x6=X[,6],") list("x7=X[,7],x8=X[,8],x9=X[,9],x10=X[,10],y0,y1,y,T)")

dataset_description: In order for the code used to create this data frame to work text files available on Dehejia's webpage list("http://www.nber.org/~rdehejia/data/nswdata2.html") need to be downloaded and stored in the working directory. The data frame consists of 297 treated units from a randomized evaluation of a labor training program, the National Supported Work (NSW) Demonstration, and 314 nonexperimental comparison units drawn from survey datasets. list() list("treated <- read.table(file = \"nswre74_treated.txt\")") list("controls <- read.table(file = \"cps3_controls.txt\")") list("nsw <- rbind(treated, controls)") list("ue <- function(x) factor(ifelse(x > 0, 0, 1))") list("UE74 <- mapply(ue, nsw[, 8])") list("UE75 <- mapply(ue, nsw[, 9])") list("nsw[, 4:7] <- lapply(nsw[, 4:7], factor)") list("lalonde <- cbind(nsw[, 1:9], UE74, UE75, nsw[, 10])") list("colnames(lalonde) <- c(\"treat\", \"age\", \"educ\", \"black\", \"hisp\", \"married\",") list("\"nodegr\", \"re74\", \"re75\", \"u74\", \"u75\", \"re78\")")

dataset_description: This data is simulated. The covariates, X, and the treatment, T, are all generated by simulating independent bernoulli distributions or from a multivariate normal distribution and then dichotomizing to get binary variables with a certain dependence structure.The code generating the data is list() list("library(bindata)") list("set.seed(9327529)") list("n<-500") list("x1 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("x25 <- rmvbin(n, bincorr=cbind(c(1,0.7),c(0.7,1)), margprob=c(0.5,0.5))") list("x34 <- rmvbin(n, bincorr=cbind(c(1,0.7),c(0.7,1)), margprob=c(0.5,0.5))") list("x2 <- x25[,1]") list("x3 <- x34[,1]") list("x4 <- x34[,2]") list("x5 <- x25[,2]") list("x6 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("x7<- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("x8 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("e0<-rnorm(n)") list("e1<-rnorm(n)") list("p <- 1/(1 + exp(3 - 1.5 * x1 - 1.5 * x2 - 1.5 * x3 - 0.1 * x4 - 0.1 * x5 - 1.3 * x8))") list("T <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = p)") list("y0 <- 4 + 2 * x1 + 3 * x4 + 5 * x5 + 2 * x6 + e0") list("y1 <- 2 + 2 * x1 + 3 * x4+ 5 * x5 + 2 * x6 + e1") list("y <- y1 * T + y0 * (1 - T)") list("datf <- data.frame(x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6, x7, x8, y0, y1, y, T)") list("datf[, 1:8] <- lapply(datf[, 1:8], factor)") list("datf[, 12] <- as.numeric(datf[, 12])")

dataset_description: This data is simulated. The covariates, X, and the treatment, T, are all generated by simulating from independent or  multivariate normal distributions and then some variables are dichotomized to get binary variables with a certain dependence structure. The code generating the data is list() list("library(bindata)") list("set.seed(9327529)") list("n<-500") list("x1 <- rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1)") list("x2 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("x25 <- rmvbin(n, bincorr=cbind(c(1,0.7),c(0.7,1)), margprob=c(0.5,0.5))") list("x2 <- x25[,1]") list("Sigma <-  matrix(c(1,0.5,0.5,1),ncol=2)") list("x34 <- mvrnorm(n, rep(0, 2), Sigma)") list("x3 <- x34[,1]") list("x4 <- x34[,2]") list("x5 <- x25[,2]") list("x6 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("x7<- rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1)") list("x8 <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = 0.5)") list("e0<-rnorm(n)") list("e1<-rnorm(n)") list("p <- 1/(1 + exp(3 - 1.2 * x1 - 3.7 * x2 - 1.5 * x3 - 0.3 * x4 - 0.3 * x5 - 1.9 * x8))") list("T <- rbinom(n, 1, prob = p)") list("y0 <- 4 + 2 * x1 + 3 * x4 + 5 * x5 + 2 * x6 + e0") list("y1 <- 2 + 2 * x1 + 3 * x4+ 5 * x5 + 2 * x6 + e1") list("y <- y1 * T + y0 * (1 - T)") list("datfc <- data.frame(x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6, x7, x8, y0, y1, y, T)") list("datfc[, c(2, 5, 6, 8)] <- lapply(datfc[, c(2, 5, 6, 8)], factor)") list("datfc[, 12] <- as.numeric(datfc[, 12])")

dataset_title: covsep: tests for determining if the covariance structure of 2-dimensional data is separable
dataset_description: Functions for testing if the covariance structure of 2-dimensional data (e.g. samples of surfaces X_i = X_i(s,t)) is separable, i.e. if cov(X) = C_1 x C_2. A complete descriptions of the implemented tests can be found in the paper arXiv:1505.02023.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: In this study the effect of biofeedback treatment on time until treatment list("success") was evaluated in patients suffering from aspiration after head and neck surgery. The outcome of interest was the time from start of treatment until the patient achieved full swallowing rehabilitation ( list("thdur") ). Patients were randomized into two groups ( list("bfb") ): one group of patients received videoendoscopic biofeedback treatment; the other group received the conservative treatment including thermal stimulation with ice and exercises for the lips, tongue, laryngeal closure and elevation. Treatment was started as soon as the healing process after surgery was finished ( list("thealing") ).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 33 observations on the following 6 variables: list("
", "    ", list(list(list("id")), list(" the patient id. ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("success")), list(" of treatment within the first 100 days; either 0 = no success or 1 = success. ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("thdur")), list(" the duration of therapy in days. ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("bfb")), list(" indicates the treatment group; either 0 = conservative or 1 = biofeedback. ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("theal")), list(" time from surgery to start of therapy in days. ")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("log2heal")), list(" log2-transformed time from surgery to start of therapy. ")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: Data were supplied by Dr. D.-M. Denk, who gave permission to freely distribute the data and use them for non-commercial purposes.
dataset_reference: Denk, D.-M. & Kaider, A. (1997). Videoendoscopic Biofeedback: A Simple Method to Improve the Efficacy of Swallowing Rehabilitation of Patients After Head and Neck Surgery. list("ORL J OTO-RHINO-LARY") list("59") , 100-105.

dataset_description: This package implements weighted estimation in Cox regression as proposed by Schemper, Wakounig and Heinze (Statistics in Medicine, 2009, c("\\Sexpr[results=rd,stage=build]{tools:::Rd_expr_doi(\"#1\")}", "10.1002/sim.3623") list("tools:::Rd_expr_doi(\"10.1002/sim.3623\")") ). Weighted Cox regression provides unbiased average hazard ratio estimates also in case of non-proportional hazards. The package provides options to estimate time-dependent effects conveniently by including interactions of covariates with arbitrary functions of time, with or without making use of the weighting option.
dataset_format: NA

Royston P and Sauerbrei W (2008). list("Multivariable Model-Building. A Pragmatic Approach to Regression\n", "Analysis Based on Fractional Polynomials for Modelling Continuous Variables.") Wiley, Chichester, UK. Sasieni P (1993). Maximum Weighted Partial Likelihood Estimators for the Cox Model. list("88") , 144-152. Schemper M (1992).  Cox Analysis of Survival Data with Non-Proportional Hazard Functions. list("J R STAT SOC D") list("41") , 455-465. Schemper M, Wakounig S and Heinze G (2009). The Estimation of Average Hazard Ratios by Weighted Cox Regression. list("Stat Med") list("28") , 2473-2489, c("\\Sexpr[results=rd,stage=build]{tools:::Rd_expr_doi(\"#1\")}", "10.1002/sim.3623") list("tools:::Rd_expr_doi(\"10.1002/sim.3623\")") . dataset_description: This dataset is the final outcome of a quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomic analysis of two samples containing different concentrations of 48 human proteins (UPS1 standard from Sigma-Aldrich) within a constant yeast background (see Giai Gianetto et al. (2016) for details). It contains the abundance values of the different human and yeast proteins identified and quantified in these two conditions. The conditions A and B represent the measured abundances of proteins when respectively 10fmol and 5fmol of UPS1 human proteins were mixed with the yeast extract before mass spectrometry analyses. Three technical replicates were acquired for each condition. To identify and quantify proteins, spectra were searched using MaxQuant (version 1.5.1.2) against the Uniprot database, the UPS database and the frequently observed contaminants database. Maximum false discovery rates were set to 0.01 at peptide and protein levels by employing a reverse database strategy. The abundance values of the dataset were obtained from LFQ values calculated using MaxQuant from MS intensity of unique peptides (see Cox et al. (2014)). The following pre-processing steps were performed to obtain these values using the Perseus toolbox (version 1.5.1.6) available in the MaxQuant environment: log2-transformation of LFQ values, filtering of proteins with at least 3 measured values in one condition and data imputation by replacing missing values with values generated from a normal distribution (see Deeb et al. (2012)). From a statistical viewpoint, the goal is to find which proteins are differentially abundant between the two conditions among the 1481 quantified proteins. Ideally, the 38 quantified human proteins (out of the original 48 ones) should be concluded as differentially abundant (in such a case the proportion of non-differentially abundant proteins will be pi0=1-38/1481).
dataset_format: A data frame with the 1481 identified proteins in row. Columns list("A.R1") , list("A.R2") and list("A.R3") correspond to the (numeric) abundance values of proteins in the three replicates of condition A. list("B.R1") list("B.R2") list("B.R3") correspond to the (numeric) abundance values of proteins in the three replicates of condition B. Column list("Welch.test.pval") contains the p-values of the Welch t-test between condition A and condition B computed with the Perseus software. list("Organism") contains categorical values: list("human") if the protein is identified as human and list("yeast") otherwise. list("Majority.protein.IDs") contains the IDs of proteins.
dataset_reference: Cox J., Hein M.Y., Luber C.A., Paron I., Nagaraj N., Mann M. Accurate proteome-wide label-free quantification by delayed normalization and maximal peptide ratio extraction, termed MaxLFQ. Mol Cell Proteomics. 2014 Sep, 13(9):2513-26. Deeb S.J., D'Souza R.C., Cox J., Schmidt-Supprian M., Mann M. Super-SILAC allows classification of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma subtypes by their protein expression profiles. Mol Cell Proteomics. 2012 May, 11(5):77-89. Giai Gianetto, Q., Combes, F., Ramus, C., Bruley, C., Couté, Y., Burger, T. (2016). Calibration plot for proteomics: A graphical tool to visually check the assumptions underlying FDR control in quantitative experiments. Proteomics, 16(1), 29-32.

dataset_description: This dataset is the final outcome of a quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomic analysis of two samples containing different concentrations of 48 human proteins (UPS1 standard from Sigma-Aldrich) within a constant yeast background (see Giai Gianetto et al. (2016) for details). It contains the abundance values of the different human and yeast proteins identified and quantified in these two conditions. The conditions A and B represent the measured abundances of proteins when respectively 25fmol and 10fmol of UPS1 human proteins were mixed with the yeast extract before mass spectrometry analyses. Three technical replicates were acquired for each condition. To identify and quantify proteins, spectra were searched using MaxQuant (version 1.5.1.2) against the Uniprot database, the UPS database and the frequently observed contaminants database. Maximum false discovery rates were set to 0.01 at peptide and protein levels by employing a reverse database strategy. The abundance values of the dataset were obtained from LFQ values calculated using MaxQuant from MS intensity of unique peptides (see Cox et al. (2014)). The following pre-processing steps were performed to obtain these values using the Perseus toolbox (version 1.5.1.6) available in the MaxQuant environment: log2-transformation of LFQ values, filtering of proteins with at least 3 measured values in one condition and data imputation by replacing missing values with values generated from a normal distribution (see Deeb et al. (2012)). From a statistical viewpoint, the goal is to find which proteins are differentially abundant between the two conditions among the 1472 quantified proteins. Ideally, the 46 quantified human proteins (out of the original 48 ones) should be concluded as differentially abundant (in such a case the proportion of non-differentially abundant proteins will be pi0=1-46/1472).
dataset_format: A data frame with the 1472 identified proteins in row. Columns list("A.R1") , list("A.R2") and list("A.R3") correspond to the (numeric) abundance values of proteins in the three replicates of condition A. list("B.R1") list("B.R2") list("B.R3") correspond to the (numeric) abundance values of proteins in the three replicates of condition B. Column list("Welch.test.pval") contains the p-values of the Welch t-test between condition A and condition B computed with the Perseus software. list("Organism") contains categorical values: list("human") if the protein is identified as human and list("yeast") otherwise. list("Majority.protein.IDs") contains the IDs of proteins.
dataset_reference: Cox J., Hein M.Y., Luber C.A., Paron I., Nagaraj N., Mann M. Accurate proteome-wide label-free quantification by delayed normalization and maximal peptide ratio extraction, termed MaxLFQ. Mol Cell Proteomics. 2014 Sep, 13(9):2513-26. Deeb S.J., D'Souza R.C., Cox J., Schmidt-Supprian M., Mann M. Super-SILAC allows classification of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma subtypes by their protein expression profiles. Mol Cell Proteomics. 2012 May, 11(5):77-89. Giai Gianetto, Q., Combes, F., Ramus, C., Bruley, C., Couté, Y., Burger, T. (2016). Calibration plot for proteomics: A graphical tool to visually check the assumptions underlying FDR control in quantitative experiments. Proteomics, 16(1), 29-32.

dataset_title: Association Between Methylation and a Phenotype of Interest
dataset_description: Is designed to test for association between methylation at CpG sites across the genome and a phenotype of interest, adjusting for any relevant covariates. The package can perform standard analyses of large datasets very quickly with no need to impute the data. It can also handle mixed effects models with chip or batch entering the model as a random intercept. Also includes tools to apply quality control filters, perform permutation tests, and create QQ plots, manhattan plots, and scatterplots for individual CpG sites. There is a tutorial for CpGassoc available at the website <genetics.emory.edu/conneely/>
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description:
The Tweedie compound Poisson distribution is a mixture of a degenerate distribution at the origin and a continuous distribution on the positive real line. It has been applied in a wide range of fields in which continuous data with exact zeros regularly arise. Nevertheless, statistical inference based on full likelihood and Bayesian methods is not available in most statistical software, largely because the distribution has an intractable density function and numerical methods that allow fast and accurate evaluation of the density did not appear until fairly recently. The list("cplm") package provides likelihood-based and Bayesian procedures for fitting common Tweedie compound Poisson linear models. In particular, models with hierarchical structures or extra zero inflation can be handled. Further, the package implements the Gini index based on an ordered version of the Lorenz curve as a robust model comparison tool involving zero-inflated and highly skewed distributions. The following features of the package may be of special interest to the users: list("
", list(), " All methods available in the package enable the index parameter (i.e., the unknown variance function) to be estimated from the data.
", list(), " The compound Poisson generalized linear model handles large data set using the bounded memory regression facility in ", list("biglm"), ".
", list(), " For mixed models, we provide likelihood-based methods using Laplace approximation and adaptive Gauss-Hermit quadrature. 
", list(), " A convenient interface is offered to fit additive models (penalized splines) using the mixed model estimation procedure.
", 
    list(), " Self-tuned Markov chain Monte Carlo procedures are available for both GLM-type and  mixed models.
", list(), " The package also implements a zero-inflated compound Poisson model, in which the observed frequency of zeros can generally be more adequately modeled. 
", list(), " We provide the Gini index based on an ordered Lorenz curve, which is better suited for model comparison involving the compound Poisson distribution.
") More information is available on the hosting web site of the project list("http://code.google.com/p/cplm/")
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference:
list("Dunn, P.K. and Smyth, G.K. (2005). Series evaluation of Tweedie exponential dispersion models densities. ", list("Statistics and Computing"), ", 15, 267-280.") list("Frees, E. W., Meyers, G. and Cummings, D. A. (2011). Summarizing Insurance Scores Using
", "a Gini Index. ", list("Journal of the American Statistical Association"), ", 495, 1085 - 1098.
") list(" Zhang, Y (2013). Likelihood-based and Bayesian Methods for Tweedie Compound Poisson Linear Mixed Models, ", list("Statistics and Computing"), ", 23, 743-757.
")

dataset_title: Classes and Methods for a Compound Poisson Linear Model Object
dataset_description: Documented here are the list("\"cplm\"") class and its derived classes list("\"cpglm\"") , list("\"cpglmm\"") list("\"bcplm\"") and list("\"zcpglm\"") . Several primitive methods and statistical methods are created to facilitate the extraction of specific slots and further statistical analysis. list("\"gini\"") is a class that stores the Gini indices and associated standard errors that could be used to perform model comparison involving the compound Poisson distribution. list("\"NullNum\"") list("\"NullList\"") list("\"NullFunc\"") list("\"ListFrame\"") are virtual classes for list("c(\"NULL\", \"numeric\")") list("c(\"NULL\",\"list\")") list("c(\"NULL\",\"function\")") list("c(\"list\",\"data.frame\")") , respectively.

dataset_description: This dataset consists of a historical sequence of the exchange rates between the Swiss Franc (CHF) and the British Pound (GBP). The value of the exchange rate was recorded at three hour intervals running from October 21st 2002, to May 15th 2007. In total, 9273 observations were made. For an example of how to use the list("cpm") package to detect changes in this data set, please see the "Streams with multiple change points' section of the package vignette, available by typing: list("vignette(\"cpm\")")
dataset_format: A three column matrix. Each observation is one row. The first column is the data, the second is the time of day at which the observation was recorded (1400 = 14:00pm, and so on), and the third is observed exchange rate.

dataset_title: Conditional Maximum Likelihood for Quadratic Exponential Models for Binary Panel Data
dataset_description: Estimation, based on conditional maximum likelihood, of the quadratic exponential model proposed by Bartolucci & Nigro (2010) and of a simplified and a modified version of this model. The quadratic exponential model is suitable for the analysis of binary longitudinal data when state dependence (further to the effect of the covariates and a time-fixed individual intercept) has to be taken into account. Therefore, this is an alternative to the dynamic logit model having the advantage of easily allowing conditional inference in order to eliminate the individual intercepts and then getting consistent estimates of the parameters of main interest (for the covariates and the lagged response). The simplified version of this model does not distinguish, as the original model does, between the last time occasion and the previous occasions. The modified version formulates in a different way the interaction terms and it may be used to test in a easy way state dependence as shown in Bartolucci, Nigro & Pigini (2013). The package also includes estimation of the dynamic logit model by a pseudo conditional estimator based on the quadratic exponential model, as proposed by Bartolucci & Nigro (2012).
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Bartolucci, F. and Nigro, V. (2010), A dynamic model for binary panel data with unobserved heterogeneity admitting a root-n consistent conditional estimator, list("Econometrica") , list("78") , 719-733. Bartolucci, F. and Nigro, V. (2012). Pseudo conditional maximum likelihood estimation of the dynamic logit model for binary panel data, list("Journal of Econometrics") list("170") , 102-116. Bartolucci, F., Nigro, V. and Pigini, C. (2013). Testing for state dependence in binary panel data with individual covariates, Econometric Reviews, in press. Cox, D. R. (1972), The Analysis of multivariate binary data, list("Applied Statistics") list("21") , 113-120.

dataset_title: Probabilistic damage tolerance analysis for fatigue cracking of metallic aerospace structures
dataset_description: Using a sampling-based approach (either sequential importance sampling explicit Monte Carlo), this package can be used to perform a probabilistic damage tolerance for aircraft structures. It can model a single crack, or two simultaneously growing fatigue cracks (the so-called continuing damage problem). With a single crack, multiple types of future repairs are possible.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: MIL-STD-1530C (USAF) "General Guidelines For Aircraft Structural Integrity Program (ASIP)", Nov 2005 list() MIL-HDBK-1823A (Department of Defense, USA) "Nondestructive Evaluation System Reliability Assessment", Apr 2009 PRoF Ver. 3.0 PRobability of Fracture, Software Package, University of Dayton Research Institute, Dayton, OH, 2005 Halbert, K. "Estimation of Probability of Failure for Damage-Tolerant Aerospace Structures" PhD Thesis, Temple University Department of Statistics, Philadelphia, PA, Apr 2014

dataset_title: Examples CP4, CP6, and CP7, adapted from PRobability Of Fracture (PROF) v3.0 documentation (in various forms).
dataset_description: Examples CP4, CP6 and CP7 are adapted from the documentation of the software PRobability Of Fracture (PROF) v3.0. The data has been modifed from the documentation in the following ways: crack growth is indexed to number of flights instead of flight hours; probability of inspection is set to 1.0; and the PROF parameter 'number of similar locations' is not part of this routine (effectively always set equal to 1). For example CP7ext, the crack growth and geometry curves have been extrapolated to a larger final crack size. The objects cp4, cp6, cp7, and cp7ext are of analysis type 'single'; i.e., there is a single damage tolerance analysis (DTA) associated with each. cp7ext.Mult.simple and cp7ext.Mult.complex are of the 'multiple' type; i.e., there are two or three DTAs associated, respectively. Finally, cp7.CD is of the continuing damage variety. Any one of these can be used as a starting point for creating a new probabilistic damage tolerance analysis problem, though it is recommended to use the appropriate type (single, multiple, or continuing damage) due to differences regarding the structure of each list. All parameters are discussed in detail below along with an indication of whether they apply to Sequential Importance Sampling (SIS) or Explicit Monte Carlo (EMC). This information is repeated from list(list("crackRinit")) .
dataset_format: List (class Sing, Mult, or CD).
dataset_source: PRoF Ver. 3.0 PRobability of Fracture, Software Package, University of Dayton Research Institute, Dayton, OH, 2005
dataset_reference: Halbert, K. "Estimation of Probability of Failure for Damage-Tolerant Aerospace Structures" PhD Thesis, Temple University Department of Statistics, Philadelphia, PA, Apr 2014

dataset_description: list("creditr") package provides useful tools for pricing credit default swaps (CDS). It enables CDS class object which has slots as name, contract, RED, date, spread, maturity, teno, coupon, recovery, currency, notional, principal, accrual, pd, price, upfront, spread.DV01, IR.DV01 and rec.risk.01, with S4 methods like update, show and summary. It also supports data frame input and is able to provide convenient calculation of key CDS statistics through functions like list("CS10") , list("IR.DV01") list("rec_risk_01") and list("spread_DV01") . Of other major functions, list("spread_to_upfront") list("upfront_to_spread") are designed to compute one of spread and upfront given the other; list("spread_to_pd") list("pd_to_spread") , similarly, can calculate one of spread and probability of default given the other; list("add_dates") list("add_conventions") compute a series of dates information and accounting conventions related to CDS pricing. Finally, list("get_rates") list("build_rates") facilitates direct fetching of relevant interest rates from online sources. Thanks to ISDA Standard Model's Open Source license, we are able to create this package for R users. You can find the Open Source licence of ISDA Standard Model at "http://www.cdsmodel.com/cdsmodel/cds-disclaimer.html?"
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This data frame is created by list("build_rates") in list("creditr") package to calculate the CDS pricing. It covers three currencies: USD, EUR, and JPY. The interest rates date from 2004-01-01 to 2014-08-23. Rates on holidays and weekends are available as well as business days.

dataset_title: The Beer Testing Data in Kunert (1998)
dataset_description: The data comes from a beer testing experiment where assessors had to rate the bitterness of five beers.
dataset_format: A matrix with 12 rows corresponding to the assessors, 5 columns corresponding to the five periods.
dataset_source: Kunert, J. (1998): Sensory experiments as crossover studies. Food Quality and Preference 9, 243-253 (table 1).

dataset_title: Experimental Design for the Beer Testing Data in Kunert (1998)
dataset_description: The design is a balanced incomplete block design with rows as blocks. If one assumes that there is a preperiod, i.e. that each assessor is given the treatment of the fifth period before the experiment starts, then the design is carryover balanced.
dataset_format: A matrix with 12 rows corresponding to the assessors, 5 columns corresponding to the five periods.
dataset_source: Kunert, J. (1998): Sensory experiments as crossover studies. Food Quality and Preference 9, 243-253 (design d4).

dataset_title: Experimental Design for the Beer Testing Data in Kunert (1998)
dataset_description: The design is a row-column design. It is actually a generalized latin square design that is also carryover balanced.
dataset_format: A matrix with 10 rows corresponding to the first 10 assessors in a fictional uniformity trial, 5 columns corresponding to the five periods.
dataset_source: Kunert, J. (1998): Sensory experiments as crossover studies. Food Quality and Preference 9, 243-253 (design f2).

dataset_title: Calculating risk contributions to standard deviation
dataset_description: This method calculates the contributions on counterparty level to the portfolio standard deviation. No data out of list("loss.dist") are required.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This method checks the input data for plausibility. The following checks are done: The PD for ratign classes should be non-decreasing according to the rating. list() The exposure should not be negative. The sector weights of each CP should not be negative and sum up to a number less or equal 1. The sector variances should not be negative.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This method calculates simple portfolio key numbers such as the expected loss ( list("EL") ), standard deviation ( list("SD") ), potential loss ( list("PL") ) and others from the original data. Later losses are discretized according to the loss unit and probabilities of default are adjusted. Also the standard deviation for the sectors will be calculated from the of the rating classes or given sector variances. Counterparties with potential loss equal to zero or PD of zero are removed for further calculations. All information will be printed.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This method uses an algorithm from Gundlach/Lehrbass p.74f to compute the loss distribution. A small modification on the structure of the two loops was done to compute the CDF parallel to the PDF and stop if a desired level is reached. Data list("a") and list("B") (corresponding to alpha and b in Gundlach/Lehrbass p.74), necessary for risk contributions, will be erased at the end if list("calc.rc") =FALSE and list("save.memory") =TRUE.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Calculating risk contributions to VaR and ES
dataset_description: This method calculates the risk contributions on counterparty level to the value at risk (VaR), expected shortfall (ES) and the corresponding TAU. The confidence level that is taken is the last entry in the models alpha vector. It is necessary, that list("loss.dist") was executed before, to compute and save required data.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: This method reads the input files list("port.name") , list("rating.scale.name") and list("sec.var.name") if needed (i.e. if list("sec.var.est") =5) from the list("path.in") directory and matches the data to the corresponding slots. Counterparties with list("NEX=0") list("LGD=0") list("CP.rating=0") or list("PD=0") are removed from the portfolio. Please make sure, that the input files have the correct form given in list(list("init")) . In the context of the main routine list("crp.CSFP") one can skip this method by setting list("skip.read=TRUE")
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Nonparametric Regression Splines with Continuous and Categorical Predictors
dataset_description: This package provides a method for nonparametric regression that combines the (global) approximation power of regression splines for continuous predictors ( list(list("x")) ) with the (local) power of kernel methods for categorical predictors ( list(list("z")) ). The user also has the option of instead using indicator bases for the categorical predictors. When the predictors contain both continuous and categorical (discrete) data types, both approaches offer more efficient estimation than the traditional sample-splitting (i.e. list("frequency") ) approach where the data is first broken into subsets governed by the categorical list("z") . To cite the list("crs") package type: list(list("citation(\"crs\")")) (without the single quotes). For a listing of all routines in the list(list("library(help=\"crs\")")) For a listing of all demos in the list(list("demo(package=\"crs\")")) For a list(list(list("vignette"))) that presents an overview of the list(list("vignette(\"crs\")"))
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference:
Li, Q. and J.S. Racine (2007), list("Nonparametric Econometrics:
", "		Theory and Practice,") Princeton University Press. Ma, S. and J.S. Racine and L. Yang (2015), list("Spline
", "  Regression in the Presence of Categorical Predictors,") Journal of Applied Econometrics, Volume 30, 705-717. Ma, S. and J.S. Racine (2013), list("Additive Regression
", "  Splines with Irrelevant Categorical and Continuous Regressors,") Statistica Sinica, Volume 23, 515-541.

dataset_title: identify cryptic relatedness in genetic association studies
dataset_description: list("CrypticIBDcheck") can be used to identify pairs of closely-related subjects based on genetic marker data from single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The package is able to accommodate SNPs in linkage disequibrium (LD), without the need to thin the markers so that they are approximately independent in the population. Sample pairs are identified as related by superposing their estimated identity-by-descent (IBD) coefficients on plots of IBD coefficients for pairs of simulated subjects from one of several common close relationships. The methods are particularly relevant to candidate-gene association studies, in which dependent SNPs cluster in a relatively small number of genes spread throughout the genome.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Data with Skewed Marginal Distributions and Gaussian Copula (Simulated)
dataset_description: This simulated benchmark data follows the model with skewed normal distribution as the marginal distribution and Gaussian copula as the dependence structure. It can be used to demonstrate the usage of methods and validation. list("DST") is the Data Simulated for Training purpose; list("DSV") is the Data Simulated for Validation (prediction) purpose.
dataset_format:
Each of list("DST") and list("DSV") is a list containing the following components: list("
", "     ", list(list(" ", list("obs ")), list("matrix of 100 observations (as row), with 80 timepoints for each")), "
", "     ", list(list(" ", list("tp  ")), list("vector of time points, with length 80")), "
", "     ", list(list(" ", list("cp  ")), list("vector of covariates for each subject, with length 100")), "
", "      ", list(list("  ", list("pars")), list("parameter list with ", list("mean, logvar"), " (matrices of 100 by 80) and ", list("shape, skew"), " (vectors of length 80)")), 
    "
", "     ", list(list(" ", list("corr")), list("correlation matrix to determine the Gaussian corpula")), "
", "     ") In addition, each data set contains one specific component: list("
", "     ", list(list(list("quantile")), list("3-dimensional array with dimension ", list("c(5, 100, 80)"), " for the true quantiles of the quantile levels 
", "      ", list("c(.50, .80, .90, .95, .99)"), "; only available for the training data set ", list("DST"))), "
", "     ", list(list(list("obs.full")), list("fully observed observation matrix with diemsnion ", list("c(100, 80)"), ", in the validation data set ", list("DSV"), ";
", "     
", "     ", list("obs"), " in ", list("DSV"), 
    "
", "     contains missing values, and ", list("obs.full"), " can be used to measure the performance of predication at those points where missing     values are observed. 
", "     ")))

dataset_description: Formalized by Krackhardt (1987), Cognitive Social Structure (CSS) network studies collect relational data on respondents direct ties and their cognition of ties among all other individuals in the network. This package provides a collection of tools for estimating a network from a random sample of CSS slices. The package also contains functions for evaluating a CSS in terms of various error types observed in each slice.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Krackhardt, D. (1987). Cognitive social structures. Social Networks 9, 109-134. list("http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0378-8733(87)90009-8") D. Yenigun, G. Ertan, M.D. Siciliano (2016). Omission and commission errors in network cognition and estimation using ROC curve. arXiv:1606.03245 [stat.CO] list("https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.03245")

dataset_title: CTL - CTL mapping in experimental crosses
dataset_description:
Analysis of experimental crosses to identify genetic markers associated with correlation changes in quantitative traits (CTL). The additional correlation information obtained can be combined with QTL information to perform de novo reconstruction of interaction networks. For more background information about the method we refer to the methodology article published in XX (201X). The R package is a basic iomplementation and it includes the following core functionality: list("
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("CTLscan")), " - Main function to scan for CTL.
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("CTLsignificant")), " - Significant interactions from a ", list(list("CTLscan")), ".
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("CTLnetwork")), " - Create a CTL network from a ", list(list("CTLscan")), ".
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("image.CTLobject")), " - Heatmap overview of a CTLscan.
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("plot.CTLscan")), " - Plot the CTL curve for a single trait.
", 
    "    ", list(), " ", list(list("ctl.circle")), " - Circle plot CTLs on single and multiple traits.
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("ctl.lineplot")), " - Line plot CTLs on single and multiple traits.
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("CTLprofiles")), " - Extract CTL interaction profiles.
", "  ") For all these functions we also provide examples and demonstrations on real genetical genomics data. We thank all contributors for publishing their data online and will accept submissions of intrestion datasets, currently ctl provides: list("
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("ath.metabolites")), " - Metabolite expression data from Arabidopsis Thaliana
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("ath.churchill")), " - Metabolite expression data from Arabidopsis Thaliana
", "    ", list(), " ", list(list("yeast.brem")), " - Gene expression data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae
", "  ")

dataset_description: A sample survey on students evaluation of the Orientation services was conducted across the 13 Faculties of University of Naples  Federico II in five waves: participants were asked to express their ratings on a 7 point scale (1 = "very unsatisfied", 7 = "extremely satisfied"). Here only the dataset collected during 2002 is loaded.
dataset_format:
The description of subjects' covariates is: list("
", list(list(list("Faculty")), list("A factor variable, with levels ranging from 1 to 13 indicating the coding 
", "for the different university faculties")), "
", list(list(list("Freqserv")), list("A factor with levels: 0 = for not regular users, 1 = for regular users")), "
", list(list(list("Age")), list("Variable indicating the age of the respondent in years")), "
", list(list(list("Gender")), list("A factor with levels: 0 = man, 1 = woman")), "
", list(list(list("Diploma")), list(
    "A factor with levels:  1 = classic studies, 2 = scientific studies, 3 = linguistic,
", " 4 = Professional, 	5 = Technical/Accountancy, 6 = others")), "
", list(list(list("Residence")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = city NA, 2 = district NA, 3 = others")), "
", " ", list(list(list("ChangeFa")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = changed faculty, 2 = not changed faculty")), "
") Analyzed ordinal variables (Likert ordinal scale): 1 = "extremely unsatisfied", 2 = "very unsatisfied", 3 = "unsatisfied", 4 = "indifferent", 5 = "satisfied", 6 = "very satisfied", 7 = "extremely satisfied" list("
", list(list(list("Informat")), list("Level of satisfaction about the collected information")), "
", list(list(list("Willingn")), list("Level of satisfaction about the willingness of the staff")), "
", list(list(list("Officeho")), list("Judgment about the Office hours")), "
", list(list(list("Competen")), list("Judgement about the competence of the staff")), "  
", list(list(list("Global")), list("Global satisfaction")), "
")

dataset_title: Relational goods and Leisure time dataset
dataset_description: This dataset consists of the results of a survey aimed at measuring the evaluation of people living in the metropolitan area of Naples, Italy, with respect to of relational goods and leisure time collected in December 2014. Every participant was asked to measure on a 10 point ordinal scale his/her personal score for several relational goods (for instance, time dedicated to friends and family) and to leisure time. In addition, the survey asked respondents to self-evaluate their level of happiness by marking a sign along a horizontal line of 110 millimeters according to their feeling, with the left-most extremity standing for "extremely unhappy", and the right-most extremity corresponding to the status "extremely happy".
dataset_format:
The description of subjects' covariates is the following: list("
", list(list(list("ID")), list("An identification number")), "
", list(list(list("Gender")), list("A factor with levels: 0 = man, 1 = woman")), "
", list(list(list("BirthMonth")), list("A variable indicating the month of  birth of the respondent")), "
", list(list(list("BirthYear")), list("A variable indicating the year of  birth of the respondent")), "
", list(list(list("Family")), list("A factor variable indicating the number of members of the family")), "
", list(list(list("Year.12")), 
    list("A factor with levels: 1 = if there is any child aged less than 12  in the family,
", " 0 = otherwise")), "
", list(list(list("EducationDegree")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = compulsory school, 2 = high school diploma,
", " 3 = Graduated-Bachelor degree, 4 = Graduated-Master degree, 5 = Post graduated")), "
", list(list(list("MaritalStatus")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = Unmarried, 2 = Married/Cohabitee, 
", "3 = Separated/Divorced, 4 = Widower")), "
", list(list(list("Residence")), 
    list("A factor with levels: 1 = City of Naples, 2 = District of Naples,
", " 3 = Others Campania, 4 = Others Italia, 5 = Foreign countries")), "
", list(list(list("Glasses")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = wearing glasses or contact lenses, 0 = otherwise")), "
", list(list(list("RightHand")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = right-handed, 0 = left-handed")), "
", list(list(list("Smoking")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = smoker, 0 = not smoker")), "
", list(list(list("WalkAlone")), list(
    "A factor with levels: 1 = usually walking alone, 0 = usually walking in company")), "
", list(list(list("job")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = Not working, 2 = Retired, 3 = occasionally, 
", "4 = fixed-term job, 5 = permanent job")), "
", list(list(list("PlaySport")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = Not playing any sport, 2 = Yes, individual sport, 
", "3 = Yes, team sport")), "
", list(list(list("Pets")), list("A factor with levels: 1 = owning a pet, 0 = not owning any pet")), "
") 1) Respondents were asked to evaluate the following items (ordered factor variables) on a 10 point Likert scale, ranging from 1 = "never, at all" to 10 = "always, a lot": list("
", list(list(list("WalkOut")), list("How often the respondent goes out for a walk")), "
", list(list(list("Parents")), list("How often respondent talks at least to one of his/her parents")), "
", list(list(list("MeetRelatives")), list("How often respondent meets his/her relatives")), "
", list(list(list("Association")), list("Frequency of involvement in volunteering or different kinds of
", " associations/parties, etc")), "
", list(list(list("RelFriends")), list("Quality of respondent's relationships with friends")), 
    "

", list(list(list("Environment")), list("Level of comfort with the surrounding environment")), "
", list(list(list("Safety")), list("Level of safety in the streets")), "
", list(list(list("EndofMonth")), list("Family making ends meet")), "
", list(list(list("MeetFriend")), list("Number of times the respondent met his/her friends during the month 
", 
        "preceding the interview")), "
", list(list(list("Physician")), list("Importance of the kindness/simpathy in the selection of respondent's physician")), "
", "    ") list("

    list(), "
", list(list(list("Walking")), list()), "

dataset_title: Posterior Results of Yassour 2009 Yeast Experiment Dataset
dataset_description: Output summarized from MCMC posterior results analyzing Yassour 2009 data.
dataset_format: These are list("list") 's containing several posterior means: list("E.Phi") for expected expression, list("b.InitList.roc") for parameters, list("AA.prob") for proportion of amino acids, list("sigmaW") for standard error of measure errors, and list("gene.length") gene length.

dataset_description: Experiments and data are obtained from Yassour et. al. (2009).
dataset_format: A list("data.frame") contains 6303 rows and 5 columns: list("ORF") is for gene names in character, and list("YPD0.1") , list("YPD0.2") list("YPD15.1") , and list("YPD15.2") are gene expressions in positive double corresponding to 4 controlled Yeast experiments.
dataset_source: list("http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2009/02/10/0812841106") list("http://www.pnas.org/content/vol0/issue2009/images/data/0812841106/DCSupplemental/SD3.xls") Yassour M, Kaplan T, Fraser HB, Levin JZ, Pfiffner J, Adiconis X, Schroth G, Luo S, Khrebtukova I, Gnirke A, Nusbaum C, Thompson DA, Friedman N, Regev A. (2009) ``Ab initio construction of a eukaryotic transcriptome by massively parallel mRNA sequencing.'' Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 106(9):3264-9. [PMID:19208812]
dataset_reference: Wallace E.W.J., Airoldi E.M., and Drummond D.A. ``Estimating Selection on Synonymous Codon Usage from Noisy Experimental Data'' Mol Biol Evol (2013) 30(6):1438--1453.

dataset_description: Fits cusp catastrophe to data using Cobb's maximum likelihood method with a different algorithm. The package contains  utility functions for plotting, and for comparing the model to linear regression and logistic curve models. The package allows for multivariate response subspace modelling in the sense of the GEMCAT software of Oliva et al.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: L. Cobb and S. Zacks (1985) list("Applications of Catastrophe Theory for Statistical Modeling in the Biosciences (article)") , Journal of the American Statistical Association, 392:793--802. P. Hartelman (1996). list("Stochastic Catastrophy Theory.") Unpublished PhD-thesis. H. L. J. van der Maas, R. Kolstein, J van der Pligt (2003). list("Sudden Transitions in Attitudes") , Sociological Methods \& Research, 32:125-152. Oliva, DeSarbo, Day, \& Jedidi. (1987) list("GEMCAT : A General Multivariate Methodology for Estimating Catastrophe Models") , Behavioral Science, 32:121-137. R. P. P. P. Grasman, H. L. J. van der Maas, \& E-J. Wagenmakers (2009). list("Fitting the Cusp\n", "  Catastrophe in R: A cusp Package Primer.") Journal of Statistical Software 32(8), 1-28. URL list(" http://www.jstatsoft.org/v32/i08/") .

dataset_description: The cuttlefish.model package was developed to provide a software application of the two-stage biomass model to assess the English Channel cuttlefish stock. Functions enable, first, the standardization of the Landings Per Unit Effort (LPUE) using the delta-GLM method. Then, 4 abundance indices, 2 derived from surveys and 2 derived from standardized LPUE, and total landings (by all gears) are used as input data to fit a two-stage biomass model and estimate the recruited biomass and the catchability of each abundance index time series.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Gras, M., Roel, B. A., Coppin, F., Foucher, E. and Robin, J.-P. (2014). A two-stage biomass model to assess the English Channel cuttlefish (Sepia officinalis L.) stock. Submitted to ICES Journal of Marine Science.

dataset_title: Data set: Simulated Pooled Repeated Measures Data
dataset_description: This is a simulated pooled repeated measures data set of patient medication adherence summaries with a binary outcome.  The independent units are the patients, and each patient has one or more measurements made at different time points in treatment, each associated with a binary outcome that could represent a diagnostic test result.  This data set is meant to be used with the list("ci.pooled.cvAUC") function.
dataset_format: A data frame.  The first column, list("id") , is the patient id.  Columns 2-5 represent medication adherence (as a percentage) averaged over the past 2, 7, 14, 21 and 28 days, respectively.  The last column is a binary outcome that could represent a test result.

dataset_title: Data set: Simulated Admissions Data with Binary Outcome
dataset_description: This is a simulated data set that represents admissions information for a graduate program in the sciences.  The binary outcome is 1 for admitted and 0 for not admitted.  This data set is meant to be used with the list("ci.cvAUC") function.
dataset_format: A data frame. The five predictor variables are: list("quant") , list("verbal") list("gpa") list("toptier") and list("research") .  We can treat , which represent quantitative and verbal GRE scores, as continuous variables.  The binary indicator variables, , indicate whether the application is coming from a ``top tier'' institution and whether or not they have prior research experience.  The binary indicator, list("Y") , represents admitted list("(Y=1)") vs. not admitted list("(Y=0)") .

dataset_title: Cross-Validated Area Under the ROC Curve Confidence Intervals
dataset_description: This package contains various tools for working with and evaluating cross-validated area under the ROC curve (AUC) estimators.  The primary functions of the package are list("ci.cvAUC") and list("ci.pooled.cvAUC") , which compute confidence intervals for cross-validated AUC estimates based on influence curves of both regular i.i.d and pooled repeated measures data.  One benefit to using influence function based confidence intervals is that they require much less computation time than bootstrapping methods.  The utility function, list("cvAUC") , which computes cross-validated AUC, is a wrapper for functions from the ROCR package.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: LeDell, Erin; Petersen, Maya L.; and van der Laan, Mark J., ``Computationally Efficient Confidence Intervals for Cross-validated Area Under the ROC Curve Estimates.''  (December 2012). U.C. Berkeley Division of Biostatistics Working Paper Series. Working Paper 304. list() list("http://biostats.bepress.com/ucbbiostat/paper304") M. J. van der Laan and S. Rose. Targeted Learning: Causal Inference for Observational and Experimental Data. Springer Series in Statistics. Springer, first edition, 2011. Tobias Sing, Oliver Sander, Niko Beerenwinkel, and Thomas Lengauer. ROCR: Visualizing classifier performance in R. Bioinformatics, 21(20):3940-3941, 2005.

dataset_title: Calculate the predictive squared correlation coefficient.
dataset_description: This package compares observation with their predictions calculated by model list("M") . It calculates the predictive squared correlation coefficient, list(list("q^2"), list("q^2")) , in comparison to the well known conventional squared correlation coefficient, list(list("r^2"), list("r^2")) %  In case the linear model \var{M} is generated on the fly, \eqn{q^2}{q^2} indicates the prediction performance of \var{M}, whereas \eqn{r^2}{r^2} is a measure for its calibration performance. %  For a given model \var{M}, \eqn{q^2}{q^2} indicates the prediction performance of \var{M}, whereas \eqn{r^2}{r^2} is a measure for its calibration performance. %  The model itself is generated on the fly (linear regression). %The prediction performance of a model can be indicated with \eqn{q^2}{q^2}, whereas \eqn{r^2}{r^2} is a measure for the calibration performance of a model.

dataset_description: 4,096 observations of inductance plethysmography data regularly sampled at 50Hz starting at 1229.98 seconds.
dataset_format: time series.
dataset_source: This data set contains 4,096 observations of inductance plethysmography data regularly sampled at 50Hz starting at 1229.98 seconds. The data were collected in an investigation of the recovery of patients after general anesthesia. The data set was used in Nason (1996) to illustrate cross-validation method for threshold selection. See the reference; Nason, G.P. (1996) Wavelet shrinkage by cross-validation. list("Journal of the Royal Statistical\n", "Society Ser. B") list("58") , 463--479.

dataset_title: Level-Dependent Cross-Validation Approach for Wavelet Thresholding
dataset_description: This package carries out level-dependent cross-validation method for the selection of thresholding value in wavelet shrinkage. This procedure is implemented by coupling a conventional cross validation with an imputation method due to a limitation of data length, a power of 2. It can be easily applied to classical leave-one-out and k-fold cross validation. Since the procedure is computationally fast, a level-dependent cross validation can be performed for wavelet shrinkage of various data such as a data with correlated errors.
dataset_format: NA

dataset_description: Lung cancer gene expression data set
dataset_format: This data set contain 56 samples and gene expression values of 200 out of 12 625 genes measured using the Affymetrix 95av2 GeneChip. The subset of genes had the 200 highest sample variances among the originally measured genes. The samples comprise 20 pulmonary carcinoid samples (Carcinoid), 13 colon cancer metastasis samples (Colon), 17 normal lung samples (Normal) and 6 small cell lung carcinoma samples (SmallCell). The rownames are affymetrix gene ids.
dataset_reference: Bhattacharjee, A., Richards, W. G., Staunton, J., Li, C., Monti, S., Vasa, P., Ladd, C., Beheshti, J., Bueno, R., Gillette, M., Loda, M., Weber, G., Mark, E. J., Lander, E. S., Wong, W., Johnson, B. E., Golub, T. R., Sugarbaker, D. J., and Meyerson, M. (2001). Classification of human lung carcinomas by mRNA expression profiling reveals distinct adenocarcinoma subclasses. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America.

dataset_title: Tally of types of teeth in some mammals.
dataset_description: A dataset containing how many of eight kinds of teeth various mammals have. This data set is a subset of the mammals dentition data in the homals package.
dataset_format: A data frame with 27 rows and 8 variables
dataset_reference: Jan de Leeuw, Patrick Mair (2009). Gifi Methods for Optimal Scaling in R: The Package homals. Journal of Statistical Software, August 2009, Volume 31, Issue 4. list("http://www.jstatsoft.org/v31/i04/paper") .

dataset_description:
Clustering is a fundamental problem in science and engineering. Many classic methods such as list(list("k")) -means, Gaussian mixture models, and hierarchical clustering, however, employ greedy algorithms which can be entrapped in local minima, sometimes drastical suboptimal ones at that. Recently introduced convex relaxations of -means and hierarchical clustering shrink cluster centroids toward one another and ensure a unique global minimizer. This package provides two variable splitting methods list("
", list(), list("Alternating Method of Multipliers (ADMM)"), "
", list(), list("Alternating Minimization Algorithm (AMA)"), "
") for solving this convex formulation of the clustering problem. We seek the centroids list(list("u_i")) that minimize list(list("
", "\frac{1}{2} \sum_i || x_i - u_i||_2^2 + \gamma \sum_l w_{l} ||u_{l1} - u_{l2} ||
")) Two penalty norms are currently supported: 1-norm and 2-norm.
dataset_format: NA
dataset_reference: Eric C. Chi and Kenneth Lange. Splitting Methods for Convex Clustering. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, in press. list("http://arxiv.org/abs/1304.0499") .

dataset_title: Deaths from various causes, in London from 1629 till 1881, with gaps

dataset_title: Root weights of tomato plants exposed to 4 different treatments

dataset_title: Yearly averages of Great Lake heights: 1918 - 2009

dataset_format: The format is: mts [1:92, 1:4] 174 174 174 174 174 ... - attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2 ..$ : NULL ..$ : chr [1:4] "Erie" "michHuron" "Ontario" "StClair" - attr(*, "tsp")= num [1:3] 1918 2009 1 - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "mts" "ts"

dataset_title: List, each of whose elements hold rows of a file, in character format

", "  ")

dataset_title: Dose-mortality data, for fumigation of codling moth with methyl bromide

A data frame with 99 observations on the following 10 variables. list("

", "    ", list(list("dead"), list("Number of insects dying")), "

    "

dataset_title: Occupation and wage profiles of British cotton workers
dataset_description: Numbers are given in different categories of worker, in each of two investigations.  The first source of information is the Board of Trade Census that was conducted on 1886.  The second is a relatively informal survey conducted by US Bureau of Labor representatives in 1889, for use in official reports.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 14 observations on the following 3 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list("census1886"), list("Numbers of workers in each of 14 different
", "      categories, according to the Board of Trade wage census that
", "    was conducted in 1886")), "
", "    ", list(list("survey1889"), list("Numbers of workers in each of 14 different
", "      categories, according to data collected in 1889 by the US Bureau
", "      of Labor, for use in a report to the US Congress and House of
", "      Representatives")), "
", "    ", list(list("avwage"), 
    list("Average wage, in pence, as estimated in the US Bureau
", "    of Labor survey")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: United States congress, House of Representatives, Sixth Annual Report of the Commissioner of Labor, 1890, Part III, Cost of Living (Washington D.C. 1891); idem.,  Seventh Annual Report of the Commissioner of Labor, 1891, Part III, Cost of Living (Washington D.C. 1892) Return of wages in the principal textile trades of the United Kingdom, with report therein. (P.P. 1889, LXX). United Kingdom Official Publication.
dataset_reference: Boot, H. M. and Maindonald, J. H. 2007. New estimates of age- and sex- specific earnings and the male-female earnings gap in the British cotton industry, 1833-1906. list("Economic History Review") . Published online 28-Aug-2007 doi: 10.1111/j.1468-0289.2007.00398.x

dataset_description: The list("nswdemo") data frame contains 722 rows and 10 columns. These data are pertinent to an investigation of the way that earnings changed, between 1974-1975 and 1978, for an experimental treatment who were given job training as compared with a control group who did not receive such training. list("psid1") data set is an alternative non-experimental "control" group. list("psid2") and list("psid3") are subsets of , designed to be better matched to the experimental data than . Note also the list("cps1") list("cps2") list("cps3") datasets ( list("DAAGxtras") ) that have been proposed as non-experimental controls.
dataset_format:
This data frame contains the following columns: list("
", "    ", list(list("trt"), list("a numeric vector 
", "identifying the study in which the subjects were enrolled
", "(0 = Control, 1 = treated).")), "
", "    ", list(list("age"), list(" age (in years).")), "
", "    ", list(list("educ"), list(" years of education.")), "
", "    ", list(list("black"), list(" (0 = not black, 1 = black).")), "
", "    ", list(list("hisp"), list(" (0 = not hispanic, 1 = hispanic).")), "
", "    ", list(list("marr"), list(" (0 = not married, 1 = married).")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list("nodeg"), list(" (0 = completed high school, 1 = dropout).")), "
", "    ", list(list("re74"), list(" real earnings in 1974.")), "
", "    ", list(list("re75"), list(" real earnings in 1975.")), "
", "    ", list(list("re78"), list(" real earnings in 1978.")), " 
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Dehejia, R.H. and Wahba, S. 1999. Causal effects in non-experimental studies: re-evaluating the evaluation of training programs. Journal of the American Statistical Association 94: 1053-1062. Lalonde, R. 1986. Evaluating the economic evaluations of training programs. American Economic Review 76: 604-620. Smith, J. A. and Todd, P.E. 2005,"Does Matching overcome. LaLonde?s critique of nonexperimental estimators", list("Journal of\n", " Econometrics") 125: 305-353. Dehejia, R.H. 2005. Practical propensity score matching: a reply to Smith and Todd. list("Journal of Econometrics") 125: 355-364.

dataset_description: Three treatments (3 samples each) were applied to Arabidopsis plants. RNA-Seq technology was used to determine messenger RNA (mRNA) counts. These were processed to remove counts for sequences that could not be identified as corresponding to a gene.
dataset_format: The matrix list("plantStressCounts") has 28775 rows, and 9 columns.  Rows have the nondescript names "Gene1" "Gene2" "Gene3" "Gene4" ... .  Columns are named "CTL1", "CTL2", "CTL3", "Light1", "Light2", "Light3", "Drought1", "Drought2", "Drought3"
dataset_source: Data are from Peter Crisp, obtained as part of his PhD work in the ARC Centre of Excellence in Plant Energy Biology at Australian National University.

dataset_format: NA

dataset_title: Lifespans of UK 1st class cricketers born prior to 1840
dataset_description: Year and birth, lifespan, etc, of British first class cricketers, born prior to 1840, whose handedness could be determined.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 211 observations on the following 8 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("left")), list("a factor with levels ", list("right"), " ", list("left"))), "
", "    ", list(list(list("year")), list("numeric, year of birth")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("life")), list("numeric, lifespan")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("dead")), list("numeric (all 1 = dead)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("acd")), list("numeric (0 = not accidental or not dead, 1
", "     = accidental death)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("kia")), list("numeric (all 0 = not killed in action)")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("inbed")), list("numeric (0 = did not die in bed, 1
", "     = died in bed)")), "
", "   ", list(list(list("cause")), list("a factor with levels ", list("alive"), " ", list("acd"), "
", "     (accidental death) ", list("inbed"), " (died in bed)")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: John Aggleton, Martin Bland. Data were collated as described in Aggleton et al.
dataset_reference: Aggleton JP, Bland JM, Kentridge RW, Neave NJ 1994.  Handedness and longevity: an archival study of cricketers.  British Medical Journal 309, 1681-1684. Bailey P, Thorne P, Wynne-Thomas P. 1993. Who's Who of Cricketers. 2nd ed, London, Hamlyn. Bland M and Altman D. 2005. Do the left-handed die young? Significance 2, 166-170.

dataset_title: Profiles of fumigant concentration over time
dataset_description: Fumigant concentrations are given at six times through a 120 minute fumigation, for seven different runs of the fumigation procedure.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 8 observations on the following 8 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("testnam")), list("a factor with levels ", list("Applied Test 1"), " ", list("Applied Test 2"), " ", list("Applied Test 3"), " ", list("Confirmation Test "), " ", list("Query"), " ", list("Applied Test 4"), " ", list("Applied Test"), " ", list("Applied Test 5"), " ", list("Applied Test 6"))), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Cultivar")), list("a factor with levels ", list("Bogapple"), "
", "      ", list("Chewton Pear"), " (the names are invented)")), "
", "    ", 
    list(list(list("X1")), list("concentration (gm/cm$^3$) at 5 minutes")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("X2")), list("concentration at 10 min")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("X3")), list("concentration at 30 min")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("X4")), list("concentration at 60 min")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("X5")), list("concentration at 90 min")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("X6")), list("concentration at 120 min")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: For s discussion of the technology, see: Maindonald, J.H.; Waddell B.C.; Birtles D.B. 1991. Response to Methyl Bromide Fumigation of Codling Moth (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) on Cherries. list("Journal of Economic Entomology") 85: 1222-1230.

dataset_description: Data on river sites was matched with data on fish caught at nearby fishing sites.  Fishing sites were classified according to type of fish ( list("Group") = fish river type).
dataset_format:
A data frame with 128 observations on the following 23 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("Group")), list("Fish river types; a factor with levels ", list("F1"), "
", "      ", list("F2"), " ", list("F3"), " ", list("F4"), " ", list("F5"), " ", list("F6"), "
", "    ")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Alk")), list("mgm/l of CaCO3")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Avrain")), list("mean annual rainfall, mm")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Bedrock")), list("% cover on river edge attached
", "      to substratum")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Boulder")), 
    list("numeric, % cover of stones ", list(list(">")), " 200mm diameter")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Cobble")), list("numeric, % cover of stones between 60 \& 200mm")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Cond")), list("electrical conductivity (", list(list("mu S/cm")), ")")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Dis")), list("maximum distance from source (m)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("DO")), list("numeric, dissolved O2, % saturation")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Elev")), list("nearest contour line (m) below site")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("Fine")), list("numeric, % cover of particles ", list(list("<")), " 0.02mm")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Gravel")), list("numeric, % cover of particles between 2 \& 20mm")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Lat")), list("latitude")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Long")), list("longitude")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("NoxN")), list("total oxidised Nitrogen (mgl/l)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Pebble")), list("numeric, % cover of stones between 20 \& 60mm")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("Ph")), list("a numeric vector")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Sand")), list("numeric, % cover of particles between 0.02 \& 2mm")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Slope")), list("numeric, elevatioon difference (m) between site
", "    \&
", "  a point 1km upstream")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Tkn")), list("total Kjeldahl Nitrogen (mgl/l)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Tpl")), list("total Phosphorus (mgl/l)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Turb")), list(
        "turbidity (NTU)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("Width")), list("modal river width (m), assessed visually")), "
", "  ")
dataset_source: Data relate to Turak and Koop (2007).
dataset_reference: Turak, E and Koop, K. Multi-attribute ecological river typology for assessing ecological condition and conservation planning. Hydrobiologica 603:83-104, 2007.

dataset_description: Words ( list("words") ), preceded by an invisible identical or unrelated list("prime") , or non-words, were flashed in front of subjects ( list("id") ). The time taken by the subject to identify the letter combination as list("not word") or list("word") was then measured.
dataset_format:
A data frame with 6381 correct responses to words on the following 10 variables. list("
", "    ", list(list(list("subjects")), list("a factor with levels ", list("1"), " to ", list("72"))), "   
", "    ", list(list(list("words")), list("a factor with levels ", list("1"), " to ", list("192"))), "
", "    ", list(list(list("e")), list("the level of familiarity, a factor with levels
", "      ", list("1"), " ", list("2"), " ", list("3"))), "
", "    ", list(list(list("ct")), list("a factor with levels ", list("HI"), " ", list("HU"), " ", list("LI"), "
", "      ", list("LU"), 
    ". Here, ", list("HI"), " = high freq, identical prime;
", "      HU = high freq, unrelated prime; ", list("LI"), " = low, identical;
", "LU = low, unrelated")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("f")), list("the word frequency, a numeric vector with values -0.5
", "      (High) and 0.5 (Low)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("p")), list("priming, a numeric vector with values -0.5
", "      (Identical word) and 0.5 (Unrelated word)")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("rt")), list(" reaction time (milliseconds), a numeric vector")), 
    "
", "    ", list(list(list("srt")), list("reaction time (sec) = ", list("rt"), "/1000, a numeric vector")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("lrt")), list("loge(reaction time), a numeric vector")), "
", "    ", list(list(list("rrt")), list("negative of speed of reaction = -1/", list("srt"), ",
", "      a numeric vector")), "
", "  ")
dataset_reference: Bodner, G.E., and Masson, M. E. J. 1997 Masked repetition priming of words and nonwords: Evidence for a nonlexical basis for priming. list("Journal of Memory and Language") list("37") , 268-293. Kinoshita, S. 2006 Additive and interactive effects of word frequency and masked repetition in the lexical decision task. list("Psychonomic Bulletin & Review") list("13") , 668-673. Kliegl, R., Masson, M. E. J. and Richter, E. M. 2008. A linear mixed-effects model analysis of masked repetition priming. list("Manuscript") .

dataset_description: The data are extracted from measures on roses from an agronomic experiment in a greenhouse and outdoors.
dataset_format:
list("roseflowers") is a list of two data frames: list("
", "    ", list(), list(list("roseflowers$variety"), ": "), list("this first data frame has 5 rows and 3 columns (factors) named
", "     ", list("place"), ", ", list("rose"), " and ", list("variety"), "."), "
", "
", "    ", list(), list(list("roseflowers$flower"), ": "), list("this second data frame has 11 cases and 5 columns named ", list("numflower"), " (the order number of the flower), ", list("rose"), ", ", list("diameter"), " and ", list("height"), " (the diameter and height of the flower), and ", 
    list("nleaves"), " (the number of the leaves of the axis)."), "
")

dataset_description: The data were collected by J.M. Rudrauf on Alsacian castles whose building period is unknown. On each castle, he measured 4 structural parameters on a sample of building stones.
dataset_format:
list("castles.nondated") is a list of two data frames: list("
", "    ", list(), list(list("castles.nondated$stones"), ": "), list("this first data frame has 2542 cases (rows) and 5 variables (columns) that are named
", "     ", list("height, width, eidgen, boss"), " (numeric) and ", list("castle"), " (factor)."), "
", "
", "    ", list(), list(list("castles.nondated$period"), ": "), list("this second data frame has 135 cases and 2 variables named ", list("castle"), " and ", list("period"), "; the column ", list("castle"), " corresponds to the levels of the factor ", 
    list("castle"), " of the first data frame; the column ", list("period"), " is a factor indicating NA as the building period is unknown."), "
") Notice that the data frames corresponding to the castles whose building period is known are those in list(list("castles.dated")) .
dataset_source: Rudrauf, J.M., Boumaza, R. (2001). Contribution <e0> l'<e9>tude de l'architecture m<e9>di<e9>vale: les caract<e9>ristiques des pierres <e0> bossage des ch<e2>teaux forts alsaciens. Centre de Recherches Arch<e9>ologiques M<e9>di<e9>vales de Saverne, 5, 5-38.

dataset_description: The data are extracted from measures on roses from an agronomic experiment in a greenhouse and outdoors.
dataset_format:
list("roseleaves") is a list of four data frames: list("
", "    ", list(), list(list("roseflowers$rose"), ": "), list("data frame with 7 rows and 3 columns (factors) named
", "     ", list("rose"), ", ", list("place"), " and ", list("variety"), "."), "
", "
", "    ", list(), list(list("roseflowers$stem"), ": "), list("data frame with 12 rows and 5 columns named ", list("rose"), ", ", list("stem"), ", ", list("date"), ", ", list("order"), " (the ramification order of the stem) and ", list("nleaves"), " (the number of leaves of the stem)."), 
    "
", "
", "    ", list(), list(list("roseflowers$leaf"), ": "), list("data frame with 35 rows and 5 columns named ", list("stem"), ", ", list("leaf"), ", ", list("rank"), " (the rank of the leaf on the stem), ", list("nleaflets"), " and ", list("lrachis"), " (the number of leaflets of the leaf and the length of its rachis)."), "
", "
